HEADLINE: Surge in Jobs Mostly Bypasses the Factory Floor

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

DATELINE: SPRINGFIELD, Ohio 

 BODY:
Barry D. Laughlin, who manages the huge Navistar International truck factory here, does not even think of hiring more workers as production ramps up in a growing economy. 
 ''We can go up in output in a lot of other ways before we have to add workers,'' Mr. Laughlin said during a recent tour of the giant elongated plant on the rural outskirts of this southern Ohio city, whose downtown streets display closed brick factory buildings on many blocks. 
 Alternatives to hiring are still so numerous at all of Navistar's truck and engine plants that employment no longer rises and falls with the ups and downs in production, as it did through the 1990's. Last year, when the weak recovery gave way to more vigorous economic growth, truck production began to increase while the work force, instead of growing as it always had in the past, kept shrinking.
 The economy is on the rebound, but Navistar -- like many manufacturers who still manage to make things in the United States -- is sticking to recession-level employment. Service sector jobs are multiplying rapidly. Manufacturing employment, on the other hand, is down nearly 3 million over the last 44 months, and while some hiring has begun, the 37,000 manufacturing jobs created so far represent a minuscule contribution to the 708,000 jobs generated over the last three months across the entire economy. 
 Manufacturers themselves warn not to expect much of a job revival at their companies. ''We have cut back on an awful lot of manpower,'' said Jerry J. Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers. ''There will be some hiring now, but it won't be extraordinary, not more than 200,000 all of this year.''
 That does not mean manufacturing is disappearing from the United States. Indeed, the companies that are most successful at keeping factories humming in America argue that new technologies, automated assembly lines, union concessions and the constant outsourcing of components to suppliers allow them to cut back on labor almost as fast as production rises. 
 ''A new structure is coming into place and until it does, that means fewer jobs, or at least not adding jobs,'' said John Zysman, co-director of the University of California's Berkeley Roundtable on the International Economy and an expert on manufacturing. 
 Such assessments fly in the face of conventional political oratory. On the campaign trail and particularly in several critical Midwest battleground states, President Bush promises that manufacturing employment will go up in tandem with an invigorated recovery, thanks to the stimulus from his tax cuts.
 John Kerry, his Democratic rival, argues that rapidly rising health insurance costs, particularly for manufacturers, have inhibited hiring and the subsidies he proposes will eliminate this drag on employment. 
 The manufacturers themselves come at the issue from a different perspective. That is as true for Intel, the huge semiconductor manufacturer, as it is for Navistar, the successor to the International Harvester Company, which went under in the 1980's. The dynamics at each are roughly the same.
 Over the last five years, Intel has constructed four factories in the United States, at an average cost of $2.5 billion apiece. The investment allowed Intel to upgrade to the production of 12-inch silicon wafers from 8 inches and to reduce the size of a transistor to a mere 90 nanometers. Making the larger wafers requires the same 5,000 factory workers, says Chuck Mulloy, an Intel spokesman. But 2.5 times the number of computer chips can be cut from the larger wafer, partly because of its additional size and partly because technology keeps shrinking the size of each chip.
 ''We do not stay in America to optimize employment; we stay to improve our productivity,'' Mr. Mulloy said, noting that most of the factories are in the West, close to Intel's design center in Hillsboro, Ore., where many employees are trained in the evolving technologies. 
 There is another element in Intel's willingness to keep manufacturing in the United States: scale. Intel dominates the worldwide market for sophisticated chips, which means it can operate its factories 24 hours a day, seven days a week. That maximizes the output of its blue-collar workers, who earn up to $60,000 a year.
 Motorola, on the other hand, with less demand for its semiconductors, has moved some production to contractors in Taiwan that achieve economies of scale by making wafers for multiple customers.
 While Intel keeps its employment unchanged as it expands output, Navistar is still cutting people. Walk the milelong assembly line at the Navistar factory here, where midsize trucks are assembled -- trucks that leave Springfield with brightly painted cabs, powerful diesel engines and bare chassis -- and at nearly every stop the same tasks are now being done by fewer people. A truck that took 102 labor hours to build nearly two years ago, now requires only 58 hours, the company says.
 Orange robots with their rhythmical, bobbing movements are almost as numerous as workers, whose numbers have declined from 4,800 in the mid-1990's to 1,100 today. Three hundred of those workers were once engaged in making the truck's cab, cutting and shaping the steel panels and welding them together. With automation, only 44 are employed in those tasks today.
 To shape the different panels, dies must be changed three times a shift, a task that once required several people and often more than an hour of downtime. One person seated at a console now manipulates the dies, which are mounted on thick flat beds that slide in and out in less than 10 minutes. 
 ''The efficiency is mainly in the speed of the die changes and the elimination of job classifications,'' said Joe Leep, who manages cab assembly.
 The United Automobile Workers, which represents Navistar's workers in Springfield and Indianapolis, agreed to work-rule changes that were crucial to the decision to retain Navistar factories in Ohio and Indiana, the two states that have suffered the most job loss in recent years. 
 The company asserts that without such concessions, the nearly $1 billion invested over the last seven years in the modernization of the truck factory here and a diesel engine plant in Indianapolis, 150 miles to the west, would probably not have happened. 
 The alternative might have been expansion of production at Navistar's equally modern diesel engine factory in Huntsville, Ala., which has nonunion workers, and the shifting of truck production to one of Navistar's other nonunion plants, or to its Escobedo, Mexico, factory where midsize trucks are assembled for sale in Latin America. 
 ''If we had not been able to squeeze out the labor, we would have had to go someplace else,'' Robert C. Lannert, Navistar's chief financial officer, said. 
 To keep the work in union plants, the U.A.W. authorized two-tier wages: new hires will start at $17 an hour, not the present $22. Fixed benefit pensions are gone; only 401(k) plans are available to newcomers. And Navistar gained the right to schedule enough mandatory overtime to raise production by 28 percent, which at the truck plant is enough to produce 226 vehicles a day, on average, up from the present 177. 
 The U.A.W. reacts angrily to what Stephen Jones, assistant director of the union's heavy truck department, describes as Navistar's ''predatory'' tactics. ''They told us they were prepared to move all of the truck production to Escobedo,'' Mr. Jones said. ''They did not move because we came up with these concessions, but they were prepared to do so.''
 But if U.A.W. concessions help to keep jobs in the Midwest, sophisticated automation and innovative manufacturing practices whittle steadily away at the total number. At one station along the assembly line in Springfield, for example, two workers once manipulated the automated rigs that turn the steel beam chasses upside down so axles can be attached more easily. Now one worker does this. 
 Or climb to the catwalk overlooking the five automated piston stuffers at the Indianapolis engine plant, where employment has declined to 1,200 workers from 1,600 in 1998. As engine blocks roll by, machines swiftly insert piston rods and pistons while, from the opposite side, connecting rods are deftly bolted around the crankshaft. Eight workers once did this task by hand; now one monitors the automated piston stuffers, which, as a final gesture, rotate the crankshafts to test the results.
 ''No one wanted to do this difficult work by hand,'' said Tom Horn, the plant manager, ''and inevitably hand-stuffing resulted in a greater number of damaged crankshafts.''
 In Springfield, truck production is moving increasingly toward the assembly of prefabricated modules, 15 in all so far, each delivered by outside suppliers, usually from the Midwest but sometimes overseas. Eaton, based in Cleveland, provides transmissions, with some imported from an Eaton factory in Brazil. The Dana Corporation, also nearby, supplies the rear axles, going abroad for some of the components, among them labor-intensive gear forgings.
 Thus does manufacturing survive in America. But if job creation is missing, skills are preserved. Navistar engineers in Indianapolis, for example, are engaged constantly in redesigning their V-8 diesel engine, to satisfy ever-stricter federal emissions standards. ''The advantage we gain is in the technology we develop,'' Mr. Hunt said.
 There is another potential benefit. Manufacturing's share of all the goods and services that America produces has fallen precipitously since the mid-1970's, when American companies began to lose their hegemony in world markets. It now represents less than 14 percent of gross domestic product, down from more than 22 percent in 1976, according to the Bureau of Economic Analysis.
 A reversal of that trend might reduce the huge trade deficit as merchandise made in America is increasingly substituted for imports. The rising output, in turn, would generate more jobs, if not in manufacturing, then in satellite industries, says Dan Luria, an economist at the Michigan Manufacturing Technology Center. 
 ''We would get the programmers, the packaging people, the testing people, the equipment maintenance companies,'' Mr. Luria said. ''The multiplier effect is considerable.''

PERSON: Kenneth Adams 

HEADLINE: If Brooklyn's Your Borough, Then He's Your Guy

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON

 BODY:
THERE is a reason that Kenneth Adams is called Mr. Brooklyn, though he demurs that this honorific is inappropriate. ''I'm more comfortable if I'm called 'the Other Mr. Brooklyn,''' says Mr. Adams, the hyperkinetic president of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce. He pipes up that the real Mr. Brooklyn is Marty Markowitz, the borough president. ''He's my friend; he's my guy.''
 Then again, everyone seems to be Mr. Adams's guy. ''I'm loving Marty. I'm loving the mayor. I'm loving Gifford.'' (That's Gifford Miller, the City Council speaker.) ''I'm loving Pataki.'' He returns to the subject later to make sure that he has expressed his love for the State Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver. ''I'm loving Speaker Silver. They're all my leaders. I love them all! They're all doing great things for Brooklyn.'' 
 Mr. Adams, who has lanky good looks and a boyish grin, is in the business of optimism. On a recent afternoon, he is found in the artsy Brooklyn waterfront neighborhood of Dumbo. He is presiding over the second annual Brooklyn Designs show, which he dreamed up to feature the works of Brooklyn-based furnishings designers and manufacturers. Dressed in a blue blazer and khakis, he arrived early for a breakfast and a press event. (He admits he has never met a microphone he did not like.)
 Mr. Adams is a relentless promoter of Brooklyn. He cheers at the thought of an Ikea store for Red Hook. The Swedish furniture giant wants to plop an enormous yellow and blue box of a megastore there in a somewhat contentious plan. Yeah, he says, his fist punches the air. Hear of a free-market, card-carrying Democrat? That would be Mr. Adams. ''I'm into free trade and market forces and Ikeas,'' he says.
 Recently, he was on public radio touting Brooklyn Healthworks, a new low-cost insurance program for small businesses. He also conceived of Brooklyn Connects, a plan to plug minority- and women-owned businesses into the borough's construction boom, and Brooklyn Eats, an annual showcase of restaurants. 
 Mr. Adams, 44, has the upbeat, genial manner of a popular television weatherman whose forecast will never call for rain. He is the former founding executive director of New York Cares, the nonprofit volunteer group for which he created a signature annual coat drive. He came to the chamber eight and a half years ago after a brief stint as head of the MetroTech Business Improvement District in downtown Brooklyn. The chamber, founded in 1918, was rather staid, an old-boy club, before Mr. Adams put it on steroids. It is now the city's largest chamber and one of the loudest mouths in the state. (He should know. He is chairman of the Chamber Alliance of New York State.) Since he took over, the chamber has doubled in size to 1,200 members, mainly small businesses.
 ''Brooklyn is not known for shy people, and certainly our chamber reflects the idea that Brooklyn is full of characters, and most of them run small businesses,'' he says.
 At the Brooklyn Designs show, Mr. Adams lopes through the warehouse on a quick, snappy tour. He cannot be coaxed into saying what design work he likes the most. ''I love them all,'' he says, a bit mischievously. The conversation then moves up the street. He sits on the terrace of Rice, a hipster, Asian-eclectic restaurant, where he takes a swig of ginger lemonade and twirls his chopsticks into a bowl of Vietnamese lemon grass chicken salad.
 Mr. Adams can tell you everything you need to know about Brooklyn: how Brooklyn is New York City's most populous borough, with 2.5 million people; how it has an unemployment rate of 8.8 percent, more than Manhattan's, similar to that of the Bronx; how the borough's economy is showing signs of growth in retail, construction, financial services and tourism. 
 ''We don't run after the sectors on the wane,'' he says. ''We really put resources in areas where growth is going on.''
 MR. ADAMS grew up in Cobble Hill. His father is a retired real estate lawyer, his mother a retired school librarian. His family goes back five generations in Brooklyn. But his voice does not have a hint of Brooklynese. What's the deal? ''My family has been around so long, it wore off,'' he quips. He says that a great-grandmother on his father's side took part in the opening-day ceremony of the Brooklyn Bridge in 1883 because her father owned a construction company that worked on it. That company later dug tunnels for the Eighth Avenue subway line.
 Mr. Adams studied Spanish literature at Middlebury College in Vermont, then spent five years in Madrid, where he ran a study abroad program for American high school students. At age 26, he returned to New York for his first foray into community development. He was a supervisor in the City Volunteer Corps, a kind of urban Peace Corps in the mayoral administration of Edward I. Koch. Mr. Adams organized volunteers in soup kitchens, park cleanups and in building renovations. Fixing up old buildings is a hobby for him. He lives in a renovated parking garage in Boerum Hill with his wife, Diana, an insurance executive, and their two daughters, ages 6 and 8. 
 So are there higher ambitions? Politics? ''That's the yikes question,'' he says. ''Down the road, I wouldn't rule it out. Certainly, it isn't happening now. I'm working hard on so many exciting projects around the borough. But government is where one can make great things happen at a larger scale.''

HEADLINE: City Rent Board Recommends Tentative, Not Firm, Increases

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN

 BODY:
In a sharp departure from tradition, which befuddled landlords and tenants alike, the New York City Rent Guidelines Board last night opted not to recommend a specific set of rent increases for one- and two-year leases on the city's one million rent stabilized apartments. 
 Instead, the board offered a tentative range of increases that will be made final on June 17 -- anywhere from 3 to 5.5 percent for one-year leases, and 5.5 to 7.5 percent for two year leases. 
 Ordinarily, the board makes a firm set of recommendations that does not change between an initial vote and the final one. But last night, Marvin Markus, the board's chairman, unveiled the concept of a range of increases before a confused audience at Cooper Union, saying that he wanted more debate. 
 ''I believe this board is not ready to make a final decision, '' Mr. Markus said. Indeed, in a sign of how divided the board was in the 5-to-4 vote, its two landlord representatives took opposite positions.
 Whatever the final numbers -- and Mr. Markus said in an interview that the board would be within its purview to go beyond the suggested ranges -- the vote clears the way for a second straight year of what tenant groups contend are unconscionable rent increases, but what landlord groups say are justifiable adjustments to compensate them for rising costs.
 Last year, the board raised rents by the biggest amounts since 1989 -- 4.5 percent for one-year leases and 7.5 percent for two-year leases.
 Last night began in typical fashion for the annual meeting. Outside, tenants denounced any increases and criticized Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who appointed a majority of the board's members; inside, tenants and landlords wore competing baseball caps and traded verbal jabs. But Mr. Markus's proposal seemed to catch everyone off guard. 
 Michael McKee, associate director of Tenants and Neighbors, a statewide advocacy group, said, ''I thought I'd seen every manipulation that Marvin Markus could come up with, but this is a doozy.'' He said that the board perhaps was trying to deflect criticism by avoiding specifics until the last minute.
 And Jack Freund, executive vice president of the Rent Stabilization Association, an owners' group, said: ''I don't think it's a good precedent. I think there's more uncertainty.''
 Of the city's three million dwelling units, about two million are occupied by renters. The national rate is one-third renters. Of those two million rental apartments, about one million are stabilized and subject to the rates set by the board.
 Since it was established in 1968 to review rent rates for the city's stabilized units, the board has never authorized a rent decrease or freeze. During the high-inflation era of the late 1970's and early 80's, the board sometimes ratified increases of up to 14 percent for two-year leases. But for most of the last decade, rents for stabilized apartments have gone up a few percentage points, in keeping with low inflation and, to a lesser degree, with annual surveys measuring landlord costs and incomes.
 In 2002, for instance, the board approved increases of 2 percent for one-year leases and 4 percent for two-year leases, even though the Price Index of Operating Costs, a summary of landlord expenses like utilities and labor, dipped for the first time. But last year, the board authorized increases that were dwarfed by a 16.9 percent jump in the index, the biggest since 1980.
 This year, landlord costs grew at a much slower pace -- 6.9 percent. Even so, landlord groups warned about the unknown impact of the city's new lead paint law.
 The law, which regulates the removal of lead-paint hazards, including dust, from apartments built before 1960, goes into effect in August. City officials and landlord groups contended that the cost could be millions of dollars, but tenant groups said that figure was exaggerated.
 At the end of the 90-minute session last night, the board also tentatively approved a range of increases for lofts and residential hotels. For lofts, the numbers were 2.5 to 5 percent for one-year leases and 5 to 7 percent for two-year leases. For hotels, the suggested annual increase was 0 to 2 percent for one-year leases, the only kind offered.
 On June 15, the public will have an opportunity to weigh in on the rent increases during an all-day hearing, also at Cooper Union. The final vote is scheduled for June 17; the resulting increases would apply to leases that are renewed between Oct. 1 of this year and Sept. 30, 2005.

SECTION: Section C; Column 4; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 11; BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE ROAD

LENGTH: 941 words

HEADLINE: Friendlier Skies on an Unfriendly Planet

BYLINE: By Joe Sharkey. 
On the Road appears each Tuesday. E-mail: Jsharkey@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
In Rome during the 1970's, I once stopped at a cafe where the proprietor kept a parrot on a perch by the bar. When the parrot abruptly uttered a sentence in Italian, I was utterly flabbergasted. 
 I've always recalled that anecdote, with some embarrassment, as a sort of personal cultural watershed. Rube from Philadelphia that I was, it had simply never struck me until then that a parrot would speak anything but English. 
 Actually, my first taste of what we now refer to as the globalization experience had come a decade earlier, courtesy of the United States military, but that didn't really count. No, the Italian-speaking parrot was my major travel eye-opener. From that point on, I realized that the world, experienced, would never accommodate even the silliest prejudices.
 That was one general attitude conveyed 10 days ago at the two-day annual conference of the World Travel and Tourism Council, which was held in Qatar and drew about 1,000 representatives from the travel industry and from world governments.
 It certainly was not lost on anybody in attendance at the glitzy Sheraton hotel in Doha, cuddled beside the Persian Gulf, that a war raged 700 miles away and that terrible passions were broiling there and around the world. Let's just say Polyanna skipped this trip. 
 Yet there was a palpable sense in Qatar that business and leisure travel, which the council says will generate a combined $3.13 trillion in global spending this year and grow steadily afterward, may with sensible guidance evolve into a viable, inexorably positive economic, political and diplomatic force.
 Expanding leisure and business travel, said Jean-Claude Baumgarten, president of the travel organization, portends ''a more mature response to a complex world.''
 The global recovery now under way in travel should accelerate this year barring any new terrorist attacks or unexpected outbreaks of disease, travel experts told the council. 
 This will occur, of course, against the backdrop of a travel industry, and especially an aviation industry, that is struggling to accommodate growing demand against cut-throat competition all over the world. Except perhaps among the top five-star hotels, which have managed to maintain their rates globally, travel suppliers aren't expecting to enjoy price increases while world business expands.
 ''I expect we should build our businesses in the travel sector assuming price deflation,'' said Stelios Haji-Ioannou, the founder of easyJet, one of Europe's leading low-cost airlines. 
 As air travel costs plunge with the proliferation of low-fare airlines all over the world, even hotels will be under greater pressure to cut rates, he said, adding, ''The price of flying and the price of accommodation is out of whack.''
 Low-fare carriers, meanwhile, are spreading even to the Middle East, long a bastion of well-protected national flag carriers. That means, as it has everywhere else, that people who seldom if ever flew suddenly are able to do so.
 Said an executive from the United Arab Emirates-based Air Arabia, which calls itself the first no-frills carrier in the Middle East: ''Of all the people who fly us, 70 percent never flew on an airplane before. They were bus riders. People in the Middle East are no different than anywhere else. They want to fly, and they want cheap seats.''
 The Middle East itself is enjoying a boom in both leisure and business travel. Dubai has already established itself as a major world destination, and its flagship airline, Emirates, routinely comes up as one of the world's favorites in polls of business travelers.
 Likewise, Qatar says it will have invested $1.4 trillion by 2014 to develop itself as a major global business and leisure-resort center. Qatar Airways, which competes with Emirates for valuable business-class travelers, is also rapidly expanding ambitiously. Last week it announced plans to fly to 70 worldwide destinations, including the United States, by the end of 2005. 
 Obviously, rosy forecasts of surging travel depend on the absence of another catastrophic terrorist attack. And travel officials -- mindful of how the SARS epidemic caused a collapse in travel in Asia last year -- are anxiously monitoring outbreaks of communicable diseases this year anywhere in the world and are getting information out sooner, with help from governments.
 On that front, lessons have been learned since early last year, when the Chinese government was slow in releasing reliable information about the spread of the SARS outbreak, said Kazem Behbehani, an assistant director general of the World Health Organization. 
 In general, ''crisis communication'' has improved markedly, he said, adding, ''If you have the information to the public, the panic will be less.'' 
 Travel being primarily a business, there is, of course, a tendency to blame the news media for spreading bad news -- even when the news is bad indeed. A survey conducted by the travel council showed that about 75 percent of its members blame the news media for making their jobs in promoting travel and tourism more difficult.
 But at the conference, reality met prejudice and seemed to win once again. ''Whingeing about the news media won't solve any problems,'' one delegate told colleagues.
 Yes, travel is a surging force for peace. But peace is not general all over the world. Let's not get carried away and shrug off the threats. Better to travel smart and prepared, experts said. As Jihad Ballout, the communications manager for the controversial Arab news organization Al Jazeera, told the delegates:
 ''The security risk is real. There is no sense of camouflaging it with an awful lot of optimism.''

LENGTH: 1092 words

HEADLINE: World Markets Fall; Lows for Year in U.S.

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Stock markets worldwide fell sharply yesterday as the prospect of higher interest rates in the United States, high oil prices and the war in Iraq unnerved investors.
 All three of Wall Street's main market gauges fell more than 1 percent to new lows for the year, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell below 10,000 for the first time since mid-December. The Dow is now off 4.4 percent for the year while the Nasdaq composite index is down 5.4 percent.
 The declines in foreign markets were steeper, as investor confidence was undermined Friday by the drop in stocks and sharp rise in interest rates in the United States on Friday. Japan's main stock index fell nearly 5 percent, while South Korea's market dropped 5.7 percent and Brazil's declined 5.4 percent. Major European markets were off more than 2 percent. 
 Despite an unexpectedly strong United States employment report on Friday, investors are focusing more on the effect of higher interest rates than on economic growth. Although the report, which showed the addition of 288,000 jobs in April, seemed to confirm that the recovery was in full swing in the United States, investors do not know how much the rise in interest rates could slow growth and corporate profits.
 In addition, there is a move among big institutional players, like Wall Street firms betting with their money and hedge funds, to reduce the risky positions they had taken when it was clear the Federal Reserve was going to keep interest rates low. Those low rates made taking on more risk cheaper and safer. 
 These risky positions include big bets in emerging markets, which fell sharply yesterday, and in the bond market, where the sell-off since April has been enough to push the yield on the Treasury's 10-year note up almost a full percentage point.
 Referring to the prospect of a Fed rate increase as soon as late June, Philip Suttle, international economist at J.P. Morgan, said the sell-offs in the stock and bond markets were ''a reminder that at inflection points like this you can get some pretty big market adjustment.'' 
 Rod Smyth, chief investment strategist at Wachovia Securities, said the hedge fund world, which magnifies its bets with billions of dollars of borrowing, ''is changing from positions it had been comfortable with for some time, and that is why you are seeing moves like this'' in stocks and bonds. 
 The direction of stock prices will depend on several factors, including how deep the current slump goes. If the three main gauges decline much further, a lot of stocks will begin to look attractive again.
 Laszlo Birinyi, who runs a research and money management firm in Westport, Conn., said that investors also needed to move past their fear of interest rate increases by the Fed. A rise in the benchmark federal funds rate on overnight loans between banks from the current 1 percent to 2 percent ''is not going to put General Motors out of business,'' he said.
 The sell-off in stocks yesterday was also prompted by a reminder of corporate scandals. 
 Citigroup announced that it was setting aside $4.95 billion for legal costs, including a settlement with investors in WorldCom and potential settlements from suits by investors in Enron.
 Shares of Citigroup fell $1.31, or 2.8 percent, to $45.41, dragging down both the Dow and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.
 Oil stocks also fell after the oil minister of Saudi Arabia called on the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries to increase output to avoid hurting the global economy. Exxon Mobil fell $1.20, or 2.8 percent, to $42.05, while ChevronTexaco was off $2.48, or 2.7 percent, to $89.17.
 The price of crude oil for June delivery, which broke through $40 a barrel in intraday trading on Friday, fell $1, or 2.5 percent, to $39.35 in New York, though gasoline prices in the United States are at record levels and the price of oil is still near a 13-year high.
 The S.&P. 500 fell 11.58 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,087.12. It is off 2.2 percent for the year and at its lowest close since Dec. 17. The Dow dropped 127.32 points, or 1.3 percent, to 9,990.02, its lowest close since Dec. 10. The Nasdaq composite index fell 21.89 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,896.07, its lowest since Nov. 11.
 Mr. Smyth, of Wachovia Securities, said in his weekly report that the stock market was stumbling because it is ''a discounting mechanism and is always looking into the future.'' 
 ''Thus stocks tend to do best when investors expect economic acceleration, for example a year ago,'' he said. ''Looking forward from today, investors are dealing with the prospect of higher interest rates, persistently high energy prices and political uncertainty.'' 
 The bond market was little changed yesterday after a sharp decline in prices and a big jump in yields on Friday after the unemployment report was released. It was the second consecutive unexpectedly strong employment report and prompted analysts, economists and investors to move up their prediction of a Fed rate increase, the first since May 2000, to as early as next month instead of later in the year or even early next year. Yesterday the yield on the 10-year Treasury note rose to 4.80 percent from 4.78 percent Friday. The price, which moves in the opposite direction, fell 5/32, to 9327/32. 
 The prospect of higher interest rates in the United States helped the dollar, which rose 0.2 percent against the euro and 1.4 percent against the yen. In afternoon trading, the euro fell to $1.1867, from $1.1895 on Friday. The dollar rose to 113.72 yen from 112.15, helped by the plunge in Japanese stocks.
 Analysts are saying that two sectors are particularly vulnerable to a rise in interest rates -- banks and other financial companies and utilities.
 Milton Ezrati, senior economic strategist at Lord, Abbett & Company, told clients yesterday: ''It is because of this consideration, though not it alone, that Lord Abbett's equity portfolios currently underweight financials significantly. Utilities, too, are rate sensitive and underweighted in part to guard against the ill effects of expected rate hikes.''

HEADLINE: France Splits With Europe Over Farm Subsidy Plan

BYLINE: By PAUL MELLER

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, May 10 

 BODY:
A surprise move by the European Commission to scrap its agricultural export subsidies to get global trade talks moving again was welcomed Monday by some of the union's trading partners, but criticized by its most important farming nation, France.
 The commission, which has the mandate to negotiate a global trade agreement on behalf of the European Union, has offered to eliminate the 2.8 billion euros ($3.3 billion) in export subsidies the union pays to its farmers, so long as other countries like the United States make similar moves. Over all, the union provides its farmers 43 billion euros ($51 billion) a year in subsidies.
 Export subsidies for farmers in the developed world were among the main issues that blocked an agreement last September at a meeting of the 148 members of the World Trade Organization in Cancun, Mexico. 
 The aim of the failed meeting, and the renewed efforts under way, is to agree to the broad terms of a new global pact intended to make trade more equitable to developing countries, and in particular to help the poorest nations, which suffer most from the protectionist policies of wealthier nations.
 Developing countries including Brazil and India walked out of the Cancun meeting saying that the world's richest nations failed to offer enough concessions on agriculture and other issues. They complained particularly about Europe's export subsidies and the United States's domestic subsidies.
 Europe's trade commissioner, Pascal Lamy, said at a news conference on Monday that the commission's initiative showed that ''we are ready to go the extra mile'' to break the deadlock in Cancun.
 The United States trade representative, Robert B. Zoellick, welcomed the commission's proposal, and said the United States would reciprocate.
 ''The United States has noted it will support the E.C.'s move by agreeing to negotiate a parallel elimination of the subsidy element within export credits, and to negotiate disciplines on food aid to preclude displacement of commercial sales,'' Mr. Zoellick said in a statement Monday.
 The United States supports its farmers' efforts to sell their produce abroad by paying them for their contributions to food aid to the world's poorest nations, and by granting them export credits, rather than straight subsidies.
 The European Union has already reduced export subsidies to 2.8 billion euros last year from around 10 billion euros ($11.9 billion) a year in 1992, while export credits to American farmers last year totaled 3.2 billion euros ($3.8 billion), the commission said, adding that American farmers get billions more in export subsidization ''under the guise of food aid.'' The United States spends around $20 billion a year subsidizing its farmers.
 France, the union's largest farming nation, said that the commission exceeded its mandate by offering to scrap all export subsidies.
 ''This idea was unilaterally advanced by Mr. Lamy; there was no debate about it in Europe,'' said the French trade minister, Francois Loos.
 Mr. Loos said it was wrong to make such an offer when countries like the United States and Australia had made no such gestures.
 ''We have made a lot of steps ahead, now we want to see others do the same,'' he said, adding that the United States has made no effort to scrap its aid to cotton exporters.
 France appeared to be isolated in its opposition to the commission's plan. Midranking trade officials from the 25 member countries of the union met Friday in Brussels to discuss the idea. ''The general atmosphere was pretty supportive,'' said one European Union diplomat, on condition of anonymity.
 Another diplomat said that although the commission did not need unanimous support from its members for its negotiating stances on trade, ''It would be hard, politically, to push ahead without the support of the union's biggest farming nation.''
 Mr. Lamy said that with presidential elections in the United States this fall, it would be hard to make progress on the trade talks, known as the Doha round, after the summer.
 ''We have a limited window of opportunity between now and the end of July,'' he said, and he urged other W.T.O. members not to let the chance pass. ''All W.T.O. members, developed and developing alike, have to translate general expressions of political commitment into concrete movement on the substance if we want to get an agreement by July.''

HEADLINE: Japan Gets a Taste of Wal-Mart

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: NUMAZU, Japan 

 BODY:
On March 31, 1854, Japan signed a trade treaty with the United States, a commercial power backed by ''black ships'' rocking at anchor off Shimoda, 40 miles south of here.
 Almost 150 years later to the day, on April 7, the latest manifestation of Yankee commercial spirit opened here: Japan's first Wal-Mart-style Supercenter -- a single-floor, 85,000-square-foot store, with wide aisles, a single bank of cash registers, parking for 574 cars and plans for 24-hour operation.
 Outside, the big red-and-white signs proclaim Seiyu, but inside the systems are largely Wal-Mart, the fruit of a two-year investment by the Arkansas-based retailer in Seiyu Ltd., Japan's fifth-largest supermarket chain. In this airy expanse, from the extra-large fresh fish counter to a wall of discounted soft drinks, the name Wal-Mart is nowhere to be found, part of a stealth campaign as the world's largest retailer enters the world's second-largest retail market. 
 The Wal-Mart name is not enough to win over customers in Japan, where recognition of the brand is low, Jeff McAllister, Wal-Mart's chief operating officer for Japan, said in Tokyo.
 More important, he said, Wal-Mart systems are already lowering prices through computerization of inventory, close coordination with suppliers and constant pressure to squeeze rents and labor costs. At this store, only 18 of the 172 ''associates'' are full-time employees, a major step toward Wal-Mart's 2007 goal of introducing Japan to its bare-bones motto, ''Every Day Low Prices.'' 
 On a recent afternoon, at this seaport 70 miles southwest of Tokyo, Seiyu's uniformed parking attendant worked furiously to find space for a constant flow of cars and minivans. Reviews by shoppers were mixed.
 ''It's big. People say it's American-style, but it's too big for Japanese,'' grumbled Yuichi Sugiyama, a 72-year-old shopper. ''I like small and cozy shops.''
 But Morihiro Watanabe, a 40-year-old city worker, said he liked the low prices, the variety and the clear signs. ''I like that they have everything on one floor, and the signs are easy to understand. I think I will become a repeat customer,'' he said.
 Wal-Mart is betting on Japan's Watanabe-sans. The gamble is that Japan is shifting from homemakers shopping by bicycle two or times a week toward couples making American-style, once-a-week outings in the van. Indeed, a big question is whether Wal-Mart can turn Seiyu around fast enough.
 In an echo of the Wal-Mart success in the United States and Mexico, the fastest growing segment in Japan's supermarket scene are stores over 100,000 square feet, larger than the superstore just opened here.
 Meanwhile, Wal-Mart is following a cautious, test-the-waters approach adopted in Japan by the world's other big supermarket chains. Over the last five years, America's Costco Wholesale Corporation, France's Carrefour and Germany's Metro -- have all opened stores in Japan. But despite new laws allowing large stores, expansion is slow. Carrefour has eight stores, Costco has four and Metro has two. In August, Britain's Tesco will acquire Japan's Fre'c Company, a chain of food markets.
 Behind the lure of Japan's $1.3 trillion market are domestic chains competing fiercely for a shrinking pie of consumer spending. Behind these chains are entrenched networks of wholesalers who doggedly defend inefficient supply chains.
 Wal-Mart has been similarly cautious, studying the Japanese market for five years before buying 6 percent of Seiyu two years ago. Last August, it increased that investment to 38 percent. In 18 months from now, in December 2005, Wal-Mart must decide whether to exercise an option to buy 54 percent, or majority control.
 Operating in nine foreign countries, including Japan, Wal-Mart has never retreated since starting its international expansion in 1991, into Mexico. Now, it will have to show that Seiyu, which lost $43 million in the first quarter, can meet Wal-Mart's profitability standards.
 Seiyu executives believe a turnaround has started. First-quarter losses were a tenth those of the same period last year. For this calendar year, Seiyu is forecasting a small profit, about $4.5 million. Setting a target of part-timers accounting for 85 percent of store staffs, Seiyu encouraged 1,600 full-time employees to take early retirement in March. 
 In a major lift for Wal-Mart, Japanese consumers are increasingly price-conscious, gripped by the sensation that their incomes are flattening or declining. 
 ''You need to assure that on a basket of goods, you are offering a meaningful difference,'' Mr. McAllister said at the Tokyo office, seated at a table littered with low-price items: $9 jeans, a 78-cent toothbrush and an 88-cent flashlight. 
 One key may be Seiyu's adoption of Retail Link, a computer system of constant inventory control, from supplier warehouses to the cash register to the clerk on an aisle with a hand-held computer.
 ''Five minutes with the computer, five minutes on the phone, and we can see sales pick up on an item in the afternoon,'' Mike Bratcher, Wal-Mart's Japan vice president for merchandising, said in Tokyo, explaining the system to a group of Japanese financial reporters.
 It is still too early to tell whether Wal-Mart's investment here will succeed.
 ''The Wal-Mart system has been adapted well at some Seiyu stores. However, it is too early to tell if Wal-Mart style is accepted by Japanese consumers,'' said Machiko Amano, a credit analyst at Standard & Poor's in Tokyo. ''Most housewives visit stores three times a week, maybe every day, compared to once a week in the United States.'' 
 ''Is there a Wal-Mart effect that is coming into Japan?'' asked Jeffrey Young, chief economist for Nikko Citigroup. ''The jury has got to be out on that.'' 
 But Wal-Mart executives believe that cars and suburban shopping are the wave of the future. While Japan's consumer pie may not grow in coming years, they say, portions will be redistributed according to companies that can exploit future trends.


GRAPHIC: Photo: Customers at the Wal-Mart-inspired Seiyu store in Numazu, about 70 miles southwest of Tokyo, get a chance to experience American-style big-box shopping. Wal-Mart owns 38 percent of Seiyu. (Photo by Franck Robichon for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: China Moves Again to Rein In Inflation

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: HONG KONG, May 10 

 BODY:
China took four more steps on Sunday and Monday to slow inflation, including setting limited price controls in provinces where the cost of living is rising fastest.
 The other steps were aimed at stanching some types of lending and development in order to cool the economy: to require more comprehensive examinations of banks' books, so as to discourage risky loans; to set stricter limits on converting farmland to industrial or residential use; and to re-evaluate previous government approvals of projects in overheated sectors like steel, cement and real estate.
 The State Development and Reform Commission in Beijing caused considerable confusion in financial markets on Monday after posting on its Internet site a vaguely worded statement requiring provinces to limit price increases. Officials in four different departments of the commission declined to comment. 
 By late Monday, business executives and economists were saying that the price controls were set on industries that are already regulated like transportation, electricity and water. Harley Seyedin, chief executive of the First Washington Group, which is based in Guangzhou and owns a power plant in Dongguan, said that he had spent the afternoon making calls about the announcement and had concluded that it would not extend price controls to any previously unregulated industries.
 Beijing has already given permission for two electricity price increases this year as coal prices have climbed quickly, with the second increase only approved on Sunday, so it was unlikely to have approved any more increases for the rest of the year anyway, Mr. Seyedin said.
 ''It really is not going to matter much, because those things are going to be regulated anyway,'' he said.
 Liang Hong, an economist in the Hong Kong offices of Goldman Sachs, said that taken together, the latest measures would not address what she described as China's two root causes of overheating investment and rising inflation: an undervalued currency, which prompts heavy speculative inflows of money, and interest rates that are extremely low when adjusted for inflation.
 ''While we maintain our view of no hard landing in China, the use of blunt administrative measures as a substitute for market-based mechanisms will increase the risk of policy error,'' she said in a report.
 The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index fell 7.7 percent here on Monday, its biggest decline in four years. The Shanghai market fell 2.2 percent on Monday and the Shenzhen market dropped 2.5 percent, part of a broader drop by Asian markets as investors responded not only to the Chinese price controls but to the strong employment figures announced Friday in the United States, after Asian markets had closed for the weekend.
 The improving job market in the United States makes it more likely that the Federal Reserve will push up short-term interest rates. Economists said that China would be more likely to raise its interest rates for the first time since 1995 if the Fed acts; for China to raise rates on its own would carry the risk of drawing in additional speculative money that would make it even harder for Beijing to fight inflation.
 Monday's confusion over price controls was the latest sign of a growing problem. As China has become one of the world's biggest economies and largest importers, its every move has become the subject of minute-by-minute scrutiny in financial markets.
 Yet many Chinese government agencies continue to issue vaguely worded statements and then refuse to elaborate, or even issue broad edicts to industries and then refuse to confirm or deny that the edicts were even issued. The China Banking Regulatory Commission issued orders to banks two weeks ago to restrict lending before the May Day holidays; the agency initially denied it had issued any instructions, then reversed itself and said that instructions had been issued, but it still has not published the details of what the instructions were.
 China has been struggling with corruption at all levels of government. But there have been no cases of officials being accused of using opaque agency statements to manipulate the markets for personal gain.
 The price control statement called for each province to limit increases if consumer prices rose a full percent from one month to the next, or were 4 percent higher than the previous year for three consecutive months. Even in provinces where prices are rising more slowly, officials were instructed to space out price increases.
 One economic mystery these days in China is the true extent of inflation. The National Statistics Bureau has scheduled an announcement on Friday of consumer inflation during April. While bureau officials have strongly denied that they have been manipulating the figures, many independent economists are suspicious.
 The bureau said last month that consumer prices rose 2.4 percent in urban areas and 4.2 percent in rural areas in the 12 months through March. Even though two-thirds of the population lives in rural areas, the bureau calculated that this meant that inflation nationwide was 3 percent. That is what China's State Council, or cabinet, has been saying for months is the maximum acceptable inflation rate.
 But the few details released by the bureau made it unclear how the rate could be so low. The bureau said, for example, that food prices, the biggest component of the consumer price index by far, were up 7.9 percent. And the main category of food -- rice and other grains -- was up 10.8 percent.
 Separate data from the People's Bank of China, the country's central bank, has shown prices rising at a much brisker pace. The bank's overall index of prices that companies pay for raw materials, intermediate goods like steel and finished goods was up 8.8 percent in the year through March.
 Wholesale rice prices were up 33.2 percent, a leap that has particularly alarmed Chinese authorities.

HEADLINE: Crisis Facing Colombians Is Called Worst In Hemisphere

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 10 

 BODY:
Colombia's drug wars have created the largest crisis for civilians in the Americas, driving two million people from their homes and threatening Indian tribes with extinction, a United nations official said on Monday.
 The official, Jan Egeland, the United Nations humanitarian coordinator, said the country was mired in debt and reluctant to divert military funds to an army of uprooted people escaping the fighting or forced off their land by cocaine traffickers.
 ''Colombia is therefore by far the biggest humanitarian catastrophe of the Western Hemisphere,'' he said at a news conference. 
 ''It has the biggest number of killings in the Western Hemisphere. It's the biggest humanitarian problem, human rights problem, the biggest conflict in the Western hemisphere.''
 He said that only Sudan and Congo had more displaced people.
 In 10 isolated areas of Colombia, which aid groups cannot reach, Indians are trapped in forests and on farms, many of them forced to flee by drug lords or rightist paramilitary gangs, Mr. Egeland said. Others have been killed.
 He said he had spent a month in the area when he was 19 but now ''all my Indian friends have been dispersed or massacred.''
 In 2002, forced internal displacement reached an all-time high of 320,000 people uprooted. The accumulative numbers since then have reached 2 million out of a country of 36 million people, threatening forecasts that Colombia's $77 billion economy will expand some 4 percent this year, he said.
 Many of the displaced are flooding into cities, including many young people with ''no hope, no education,'' making them ripe for recruitment into guerrilla, paramilitary or drug gangs, Mr. Egeland said.
 The uprooted people go to cities in large numbers, where they live in shantytowns, like the one outside Cartagena, which has 10,000 people ''floating in a sea of sewage and garbage.''
 Mr. Egeland said he had discussed with President Alvaro Uribe a new plan to coordinate foreign aid in the country. The United Nations last appealed for $80 million in funds in 2002 but received only $33.6 million.

HEADLINE: UBS Fined $100 Million Over Trading of Dollars

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve fined Switzerland's largest bank, UBS, $100 million on Monday, accusing it of violating United States trade sanctions by sending dollars to Cuba, Iran, Libya and Yugoslavia.
 UBS operated a trading center for dollars in its Zurich headquarters under contract with the Federal Reserve of New York, to help circulate new United States notes and retire old ones. 
 A condition of the arrangement was that UBS not deliver or accept dollar notes to or from banks in countries under trade sanctions. 
 In an announcement, the Federal Reserve said that UBS had violated the agreement and that some former officers and employees of the bank, whom it did not identify, intentionally concealed the transactions by falsifying monthly reports made to the Fed. 
 The individuals were not part of the order issued Monday by the Fed, in which UBS agreed to pay a $100 million fine without admitting to the accusations.
 The bank, which is no longer in the business of trading international banknotes, said Monday that some employees had been fired and disciplinary measures had been taken against others.
 The violations reportedly occurred throughout the duration of UBS's contract with the New York Fed, from 1996 through October 2003, when the Fed terminated it.
 The Swiss Federal Banking Commission reprimanded UBS and said it would inspect its operations to ensure that corrective actions were effective.
 ''UBS recognizes that very serious mistakes were made, accepts the sanctions and expresses its regret,'' the bank said. ''It has already instituted corrective and disciplinary measures and has decided to exit the international banknote trading business.''
 Roughly two-thirds of the $669 billion in United States currency circulates abroad. Five other institutions -- American Express, Bank of America, HSBC, Royal Bank of Scotland and United Overseas Bank -- operate eight trading centers, known as Extended Custodial Inventory facilities, in Europe and Asia under contract with the Fed.

HEADLINE: Struggling to Cut Its Costs, Delta Weighs Bankruptcy Filing

BYLINE: By MICHELINE MAYNARD

 BODY:
Delta Air Lines, battling with its pilots' union over its effort to cut labor costs, said yesterday that it might have to seek bankruptcy protection unless it can obtain contract concessions. 
 The disclosure, which sent Delta's stock tumbling, came three days after a similar warning by US Airways. 
 Delta's disclosure, made in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, was its first acknowledgment that it might face a Chapter 11 filing. 
 Last month, the airline's chief executive, Gerald Grinstein, insisted that Delta could get through a lingering financial crisis without seeking bankruptcy protection. 
 But in the S.E.C. filing, Delta said it ''will need to pursue alternative courses of action intended to make us viable for the long term'' unless it can make its costs competitive, start earning sustained profits again and get access to capital markets.
 Those alternatives include ''the possibility of seeking to restructure our costs under Chapter 11 restructuring,'' the airline said.
 Shares of Delta fell 84 cents, to $4.54, down about 16 percent. 
 A spokesman for the airline said Delta was not departing from its vow to avoid a bankruptcy filing, but acknowledging that Chapter 11 was an option.
 Industry analysts have been concerned for months about the prospects for Delta, which is based in Atlanta. The airline, the nation's third largest behind American Airlines and United Airlines, lost $383 million in the first quarter, about $33 million more than it had forecast, in large part because of skyrocketing jet fuel costs, which are up more than 40 percent over the last year.
 Delta's two biggest rivals, American and United, have each won significant reductions in labor costs from their unions. American did it last year after threatening a bankruptcy filing, while United negotiated its cuts under Chapter 11 bankruptcy, which it sought in December 2002; it has yet to emerge. Before those cuts, Delta's overall costs were the lowest among the traditional major airlines; now, the airline said, they are among the highest, and roughly double those of low-fare airlines like Southwest Airlines or JetBlue. The situation ''places us at a serious competitive disadvantage,'' Delta said in the filing.
 In November, Delta replaced its chief executive, Leo F. Mullin, with Mr. Grinstein, a board member and former chief executive of Western Airlines. After taking charge on Jan. 1, Mr. Grinstein ordered a top-to-bottom review of the airline's operations, but he said last month that he did not expect to present a restructuring plan to its board before late summer.
 Mr. Mullin's inability to persuade Delta's pilots to grant concessions was seen as a reason why he departed. Delta's contract with the Air Line Pilots Association does not expire until 2005, and the union is not required to hold talks with the company until later this year. The union has said it would be willing to give up a wage increase scheduled for this month and take a 9 percent cut in pay, and reiterated yesterday that it was willing to work with the airline to cut its costs. But Delta is seeking a 30-percent cut in pilots' pay, which the union has called unacceptable.
 Delta's filing with the S.E.C. came as Southwest Airlines formally inaugurated its service to Philadelphia, challenging struggling US Airways in one of its three main hubs (the others are Pittsburgh and Charlotte). 
 US Airways wants its labor unions, which granted two sets of concessions while US Airways was in bankruptcy protection, to give a third round by midsummer; otherwise, it said on Friday, it may have to sell assets or file for bankruptcy again. 
 Only its pilots' union has agreed to negotiate; other unions have said they would be willing to help the airline save money, but not reopen their contracts.

HEADLINE: Making the World Safer, One Client at a Time

BYLINE: By HARRY HURT III

 BODY:
Denzel Washington may owe his life to Chris Palmer.
 Unlike Mr. Washington, who stars in 20th Century Fox's new action film ''Man on Fire,'' Mr. Palmer is not a Hollywood leading man. Balding, bearded and heavy-set, with a passing resemblance to Orson Welles, Mr. Palmer, 41, is director of risk control for the Albert G. Ruben unit of the insurance broker Aon; Ruben provides security for film studios. 
 The opening credits of ''Man on Fire,'' which centers on a kidnapping plot in Mexico City, state that a kidnapping takes place every 60 minutes in Latin America and that 70 percent of the victims do not survive. According to Mr. Palmer, 10 to 20 kidnappings occur each day in Mexico City alone, making it second only to Medellin, the drug center in Colombia, as the kidnapping capital of the world.
 Working with Giuliani Protocol, an Aon subsidiary formed in partnership with the firm run by the former mayor of New York, Rudolph W. Giuliani, Mr. Palmer looked after Mr. Washington and his fellow filmmakers in Mexico City in 2002 by providing drivers and bodyguards.
 He also established ''safe zones'' in the city so that the crew could have secure access to restaurants, dry cleaners and other retail stores, many of them with their own armed guards. The filming was completed without incident. ''There have been no kidnappings on any of my movies,'' Mr. Palmer said.
 In February, Mr. Palmer and his colleagues at Albert G. Ruben released an icon-studded map with the title Risks in Global Filmmaking. The map rates threats to health and safety in every country. Although the map was produced for the Hollywood clientele, its lessons hold for most business travelers. 
 ''Anyone in a Fortune 500 company is definitely at risk when they travel today, especially if they're with a company that's well known overseas, like an I.B.M. or a Coca-Cola,'' Mr. Palmer said.
 Worldwide political and economic turmoil is causing leading security firms to offer services similar to Mr. Palmer's. In March, Kroll, a publicly traded risk consultant, formed a London subsidiary for corporate and government clients headed by a former Special Air Service officer.
 ''The intense hostility that corporations and government agencies face in diverse world regions has created an unprecedented demand for services to ensure the security of people, property and operations,'' said Michael Cherkasky, Kroll's president and chief operating officer. 
 Frequent overseas business travelers like Steve Cone, head of global marketing for Citigroup's global investment management unit, attest to the need for professional help. On Sept. 11, 2001, Mr. Cone evacuated his office in 7 World Trade Center shortly before the building collapsed. Since then, he has traveled widely with a new wariness. 
 ''People need to be cognizant of what's safe behavior in a particular country and what isn't,'' he said. He says he reads the fine print in his passport on how to dress and act overseas.
 Mr. Palmer is a kind of uber-overseas business traveler who has worked in more than 70 countries, often spending months at film locations. Born in Costa Rica and the son of a former United States Army helicopter pilot and Central Intelligence Agency operative, he is certified by the Federal Emergency Management Agency and the Federal Bureau of Investigation in emergency response to terrorism and is a member of the State Department's Overseas Security Advisory Council.
 His global-risks map highlights both obvious and not-so-obvious dangers. It features icons with a five-point scale covering crime, organized crime and corruption, kidnapping, disease and medical care. Although the map includes terrorism alerts in its monthly updates, a separate Aon unit produces another map devoted to terrorism risks.
 Mr. Palmer claims that most American business travelers remain blithely unaware of the dangers they face around the world, apart from those in obvious trouble spots like Iraq. ''Most of what Americans know about safety risks overseas comes from CNN and the newspapers,'' he said. ''But the U.S. media only covers about 1 percent of what is happening around the world in terms of terrorism, crime and organized crime.''
 He urges clients to discard outdated assumptions and face up to uncomfortable new realities. For example, he says, kidnappers in Mexico City are just as likely to pursue business travelers as rich industrialists or movie stars. ''Anyone who travels with credit cards and A.T.M. cards, which is just about everybody, is at risk in Mexico City,'' he said. ''The bad guys kidnap you and hold you until they get your PIN numbers and empty out your accounts.'' 
 Other places with a high risk of kidnapping, according to Mr. Palmer, include Argentina, Brazil, India and the Philippines. 
 Another growing threat is street crime. He says Johannesburg has the highest car-jacking rate in the world and, in part because of the prevalence of that crime, the second-highest murder rate. Organized crime and official corruption are rampant in Eastern Europe, Russia and other nations in the Commonwealth of Independent States. According to Mr. Palmer, the Russian mafia's stranglehold means that travelers run the risk not just of abductions but also demands for bribes and protection money. 
 Inadequate medical care can also pose a lethal hazard, and not just in the impoverished nations of sub-Saharan Africa. Malta, a popular tourist destination, has three functioning ambulances, Mr. Palmer says, and Barbados one. American travelers should also be vigilant about outbreaks of infectious diseases, he says, citing the spread of malaria in Bolivia, Brazil, Ecuador and Peru and recent outbreaks of hepatitis A and B and of polio in Russia and Kazakhstan.
 One bright spot on the global-risks map is Morocco, where the rating of the kidnap-and-ransom risk was recently lowered to 3 from 5. ''The threat has dropped substantially because the Moroccan government has worked with the U.S. government to root out a home-grown terrorist group inspired by Al Qaeda,'' Mr. Palmer said.
 Among the havens are Iceland and Greenland, which benefit from sparse populations and remoteness, and Canada, which has remained immune from terrorist threats. No fool, Mr. Palmer often speaks French when checking into hotels. ''People think I'm a Canadian,'' he says.

HEADLINE: The Mixed-Up Politics of the Deficit

BYLINE: By Robert B. Reich. 
Robert B. Reich, the author of ''Reason: Why Liberals Will Win the Battle for America,'' was secretary of labor from 1993 to 1997.

DATELINE: WALTHAM, Mass. 

 BODY:
If soaring deficits are such a big problem, why haven't long-term interest rates also risen? Could it be that John Kerry is wrong when he says that the Bush administration's deficits threaten to become a ''fiscal cancer that will erode any recovery and threaten the prospect of lasting prosperity'' -- and Dick Cheney was right when, according to former Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill, he said that ''deficits don't matter''?
 It's unlikely. The more plausible explanation has more to do with politics than economics: the parties have reversed roles, or at least perceptions of them have changed drastically. The Democrats have become the eat-your-spinach party, preaching the virtues of fiscal restraint, while Republicans invite Americans to a free lunch. 
 The evidence is compelling. In the last three years, upper-income Americans have been treated to vast tax cuts, with promises of more, while government spending has ballooned. This year's deficit, according to the White House's latest estimate, will be a record $521 billion -- an estimated 4.2 percent of the total economy. If President Bush succeeds in making his tax cuts permanent, future deficits will be much larger.
 According to most mainstream economists -- and the stock market, which yesterday dropped below 10,000 for the first time in six months -- a day of reckoning awaits. No less an authority than Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve and a former enthusiast of the Bush tax cuts, has warned that the deficits pose ''a significant obstacle to long-term stability.''
 The Fed is now widely expected to raise short-term rates at its meeting next month, and the yield on 10-year Treasury notes has been inching higher. But if the market were behaving rationally, long-term rates would already be far higher in anticipation of an interest-rate crunch. Who in their right mind would lend dollars today, to be repaid in 3 or 5 or 10 years, without insisting that debtors pay substantial interest?
 John Kerry's economic plan -- rolling back the Bush tax cut for people earning more than $200,000 and re-establishing strict rules requiring that any new spending be offset with other spending cuts or new revenue -- is based on this view. Yet so far, the vast increase in government borrowing hasn't affected long-term rates that much.
 Capital markets do not always behave rationally, of course. Perhaps bond traders just aren't paying attention to the gathering storm. Maybe they've been distracted by the Fed's low short-term rates. Maybe they're Republicans.
 Another explanation is more consistent with economic and political rationality. Bill Clinton, and now John Kerry, have taught the bond traders on Wall Street an important and comforting lesson: no matter how big deficits grow under Republican presidents, eventually a Democratic president will come along to clean up the mess. That confidence is helping to keep long-term rates down, despite the current out-of-control deficits.
 More than a decade ago, the federal deficit was more than $300 billion -- about 5 percent of the economy. President Bill Clinton and Congressional Democrats reversed this profligate trend by slashing spending and raising taxes. The strategy was hard to swallow, and not at all popular -- not a single Republican member of Congress voted for Mr. Clinton's 1993 budget. Some of us in the president's cabinet thought he had gone further than he needed to; there was too little money left for education, job training and health care.
 But there is no disputing that the plan had the intended effect. Deficits that had ballooned under Ronald Reagan and George H. W. Bush were brought firmly under control. Bond traders breathed great sighs of relief. Wall Street beamed.
 Mr. Kerry has wisely and responsibly decided to take the same route. If he becomes president next January, he will inherit a budget mess not unlike that which Mr. Clinton inherited. And Mr. Kerry has already committed himself to following Mr. Clinton's lead and imposing fiscal restraint. He has scaled back some of his more ambitious spending plans, and has somberly told his Democratic audiences that the country must get its fiscal house in order before addressing the larger needs of society.
 Undoubtedly, Mr. Kerry's resolve has contributed to the bond traders' calm. In the event that Mr. Kerry is not elected and President Bush gets a second term, the fiscal picture will become substantially worse. But bond traders will still take comfort in the knowledge that another Democrat will eventually come along to fix it.
 You see, Democrats and Republicans are engaged in the economic equivalent of Nixon going to China: Republican presidents can get away with utterly irresponsible fiscal policies because there's no one to their right who will make too much trouble for them. Democratic presidents can get away with fiscal austerity because there's no one to their left who will make their life too difficult. But the irony should not be missed. John Kerry's promise of fiscal responsibility might just save George Bush's presidency.

HEADLINE: The Marines Enter Falluja, With Peace Their Aim

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER

DATELINE: FALLUJA, Iraq, May 10 

 BODY:
In a tiny, carefully choreographed convoy, and with not a shot fired, American marines on Monday made their way into the embattled city of Falluja, where a two-star general met for 25 minutes with his anointed local leaders on sullenly quiet streets.
 Whether the meeting was a historic breakthrough, as the marines maintained afterward, or just another step in the Americans' effort to bring some sort of order to a country they have conquered but not fully subdued, remained to be seen.
 What was clear was that it was another shift in the American effort to get control of the situation -- this time, perhaps, by attaching itself to whatever local authority might be seen as legitimate, even if it was a holdover from Saddam Hussein's rule. Similar efforts appeared to be under way with the Shiite tribal leadership in the south in an attempt to undermine the insurgency led by the rebel cleric Moktada al-Sadr. 
 The foray into the city, the product of intensive and frequently revised planning, was in stark contrast to the American approach through the past month.
 The rebellious city had been under military siege since April 5, after four American contractors were brutally slain in an ambush and their bodies defiled by a mob. Hundreds of local citizens and dozens of marines have been killed in street fighting. 
 But on Monday, the tough talk the marines had made over the previous month -- that the killers must be turned over, that foreign fighters the marines believe have been holed up in the city must be surrendered and that all heavy weapons must be turned over -- was noticeably gone.
 Instead, Maj. Gen. James N. Mattis, the commander of the First Marine Division, told 14 sheiks and several other civic leaders about $40 million the marines had set aside for rebuilding the city, chunks of which have been destroyed in the fighting. He talked of ''making Falluja a great city once again.''
 The general's earnestness was also illustrated by some 2,000 wheelbarrows piled up in pieces at their negotiation place for a community cleanup -- although, in truth, much of the city consists of dirt.
 The plan for the convoy had gone through a number of permutations. At first it was seen by planners as a show of strength, with preparations worthy of a major invasion, including tank support and air cover -- a ''thunder run,'' as they called it, into the city.
 The operation was revised, scaled down, postponed and, apparently, nearly abandoned.
 Then, at a three-hour meeting on Sunday afternoon, the plan was suddenly revived at the request of the city's new American-appointed overseer, Muhammad Latif, a Sunni Muslim and onetime intelligence colonel in the old Iraqi Army who was said to have been fired and jailed by Mr. Hussein after going to staff college in Britain.
 Mr. Latif, in his usual European-cut gray suit, had played a behind-the-scenes role in negotiations with the Americans until they appointed the first general to head a new Iraqi security force in Falluja, Maj. Gen. Jasim Muhammad Saleh. The very picture of a Hussein-era officer, complete with thick mustache and old green uniform with swords and eagles on his shoulders, General Saleh was found to have been a commander of the feared Republican Guard and was quickly replaced. 
 The new version of the foray into the city was evidently intended to reinforce Mr. Latif's grip on power. The streets were lined with his men. 
 But the shops along the way were closed and deserted, and only a few men were out to watch, clustered in small groups, arms folded over their chests. They stared glumly at the joint convoy of 10 American armored vehicles and Humvees, accompanied by an equal number of white Nissan pickup trucks piled high with Iraqi police officers, the lead truck waving an old-style Iraqi flag. 
 The convoy went only a short distance into town, stopping at the mayor's office for tea, and did not venture into the tough neighborhoods where the Americans had fought insurgents.
 ''They don't like us,'' an American marine observed, looking over his machine gun in the turret of an armored vehicle.
 Although the convoy itself was small, the security, under the direction of the Third Battalion, Fourth Marines, regarded as a particularly tough outfit and headed by Lt. Col. B. P. McCoy, was heavy. Two companies were posted as a quick-reaction force in case of trouble, and Predator drones and combat aircraft hovered overhead. 
 The troops gathered overnight and slept in a stony field, moving out at dawn. General Mattis, a combative commander who is revered by his men as a kind of warrior monk, had earlier laid out a battle plan to conquer the insurgents. Now he found himself in the role of peacemaker.
 ''My fine young sailors and marines,'' he said to the men in battle gear gathered around him after the convoy's safe return. ''Sometimes history is made in small, dusty places like this. Today was good history because we did not get into a fight. Not a shot was fired. We did not come here to fight these people, we came here to free them.''

HEADLINE: Faulting the Administration, Kerry Vows to Rein In Health Care Premiums

BYLINE: By JODI WILGOREN

DATELINE: EDINBORO, Pa., May 10 

 BODY:
Saying the Bush administration had failed to react to spiraling health care premiums, Senator John Kerry vowed on Monday to cut those costs by about 10 percent, or $1,000, per family.
 ''Mine is a plan that will cut soaring premiums, cut the waste, cut the greed, and cut Americans a good deal,'' Mr. Kerry, the presumed Democratic presidential nominee, told several hundred people, of his proposal to have the federal government assume the responsibility for catastrophic care, a move intended to reduce health insurance costs.
 ''It's a plan that finally makes our health care affordable, which also makes our businesses all across America more competitive,'' he said to an audience, which included many nurses and nursing students, at a local university here in Pennsylvania's northwest corner. 
 With his speech, Mr. Kerry began a four-day focus on health care, reprising proposals he made during the Democratic primary even as Washington and much of the rest of the country remained consumed by the Iraqi prisoner abuse scandal.
 While the policy is not new, the senator's approach showed how the Kerry campaign plans to integrate health insurance into its larger economic message about creating jobs.
 Instead of talking about universal access and the estimated 43 million uninsured Americans, a rallying cry for liberals concerned about the poor, Mr. Kerry emphasized costs, a hot-button issue for both middle-class voters and businesses. He stood in front of a banner emblazoned with the slogan, ''Affordable health care means a stronger America.''
 Sharing hard-luck stories of people he had met at campaign events who lack health insurance or spend their monthly income at their local pharmacy, Mr. Kerry added: ''Today, a regular checkup is emptying the family checkbook. Waiting for a doctor's bill is causing as much anxiety as waiting for a diagnosis.''
 Sarah Bianchi, Mr. Kerry's policy director, said, ''We're making this a major part of our economic contrast with Bush.'' The campaign issued a 13-page report filled with grim statistics, most from a recent report by the Kaiser Family Foundation, to buttress the argument that Mr. Bush has done little to control health care costs.
 Among the bullet points: premiums, which include the costs paid by both workers and their employees, jumped 41 percent, to $9,549 from $6,772, from 2000 to 2003; premiums increased 13.9 percent last year while earnings rose 3.1 percent; and spending on prescriptions has doubled since 1998 to $184 billion. 
 The report also said that for the first time, the typical person had to work 31 days to pay for health care, and that America spent more per capita on health care -- $4,887 -- than nine industrialized democracies, including Switzerland, Canada, Sweden, Japan and New Zealand.
 Mr. Kerry's focus on health care was amplified by other Democrats, with Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, one of the senator's Democratic primary rivals, accusing the Bush administration of protecting the pharmaceutical and health insurance industries.
 The Bush campaign accused Mr. Kerry of skipping votes, while he has been campaigning, on both the Medicare prescription drug bill and legislation to curb medical malpractice suits. Bush aides also circulated criticism of Mr. Kerry's health care plan previously made by Mr. Gephardt.
 Responding to Mr. Kerry, Representative Bill Thomas, Republican of California, said in the Bush campaign's daily conference call, that ''the president with his leadership has tried to address some of the areas where spiraling costs occur.'' Mr. Thomas said many indicators cited by the Democrats had been rising steadily for 10 or 20 years. Mr. Kerry's plan ''isn't reducing the cost,'' he said, ''it's simply shifting from one pocket, payment at work, to the other pocket, payment in taxes.''
 Stephanie Cutter, Mr. Kerry's communications director, noted that the Democrat had returned to Capitol Hill to try to block the Bush administration's prescription drug bill, but ''when that effort failed, and it was clear the bill would pass, Kerry felt it was more important to get back on the campaign trail and talk to seniors about their needs and how to address those needs.''
 Mr. Kerry accused the Bush administration of lacking a plan to reduce costs or expand health insurance coverage, saying, ''You almost never hear the words 'health care' come out of the president's mouth.''
 In contrast, Mr. Kerry plans to talk about little else this week, here in Pennsylvania and in Kentucky, Florida and Arkansas.
