HEADLINE: 'My Fair Lady' In Miniature

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J. 

 BODY:
As you might expect, the high society dress-up costumes are showy and elegant, especially the hats. The music rings a bell. And the lyrics seem familiar, even if you can't quite remember them without a cue:
 Every duke and earl and peer is here.
 Everyone who should be here is here. 
 The scene is the ''Ascot Gavotte,'' the spectacle of gorgeosity from that musical of musicals from 1956, ''My Fair Lady.'' It's the scene known for setting a breathtaking standard of extravagance on the stage that was only amplified in the 1964 screen version, and for inflating a huge balloon of pomposity that is gloriously punctured by the musical theater's most beloved societal interloper, Eliza Doolittle. You remember her ill-mannered exhortation of the nag Dover: ''Move yer bloomin' arse!''
 Here at the McCarter Theater Center, however, the new jewel-box second stage, the Berlind Theater, makes little of this possible. The stage measures only a few hoop skirts wide, it seems, hardly enough for a fashion parade, much less any kind of dance, an orchestra or a chorus.
 The ''My Fair Lady'' that opened here on Wednesday is likely to dash the expectations of anyone seeking the efflorescent pomp of the original or any of the show's myriad restagings. The imaginative product of two affable and boyish Chicagoans, the stage director Gary Griffin and the musical director Thomas Murray, this is ''My Fair Lady'' in miniature. They haven't cut any scenes or songs; virtually all of the original dialogue remains in place. But performed on an essentially bare stage, without a choreographer or a chorus, with a cast of a mere 10 and two pianos sitting in for an orchestra, the show bears more resemblance to its archly satiric source material (Shaw's ''Pygmalion,'' if you must be reminded) than to the luscious, clever musical written by Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe and initially directed with the juiciest panache by Moss Hart. 
 The natural question is, why? Why strip a beloved musical of the very thing that makes it beloved? For Mr. Griffin and Mr. Murray, the better question is, why not? Why not see what else is hidden in the folds of a great work of art?
 ''It's like any great play, any classic,'' said Mr. Griffin, 43. ''It's there for re-examining, as long as you treat it with respect.''
 The re-examination, in this case, has to do with analyzing the story ''My Fair Lady'' tells, identifying its essentials and re-envisioning the musical. That is, Mr. Griffin and Mr. Murray did not shrink ''My Fair Lady'' from its accepted size; they built it from scratch on a different scale.
 ''I like to work on music theater the way you work on a great play,'' said Mr. Griffin, a veteran director around Chicago who is probably best known to New York theatergoers for the concert versions of ''Pardon My English'' in March and ''The New Moon,'' presented last year, in the Encores! series at City Center. ''Sometimes music theater relies on cliche or spectacle to pump up a moment and create an emotion we know how to respond to. And what Tom and I like to work on is not trying to develop the music theater moment, but trying to figure out the truthful event that's going on with the characters that the music can shape and reflect.''
 Mr. Murray, 37, added that in a musical like ''My Fair Lady,'' there is a great deal to discover. You can go through the show, he said, and see where the creators added sweep and spectacle to the foundation. 
 ''But it's not as if, in the writing, Lerner said to himself, 'Well, this is a big moment so I can write fluff lyrics,' '' Mr. Murray said. ''So when we decided we were going to look at some of the big scenes, we found a lot already there for us to use.'' 

Variations on the Familiar
 The Ascot scene is a case in point. In Mr. Griffin's staging there is no procession; instead, 9 of the show's 10 actors enter and exit in different groupings. (Michael McCarty, who plays Alfred P. Doolittle, Eliza's good-for-nothing charmer of a father, is the absentee.) And the scene becomes a series of brief glimpses into developing relationships. 
 With no chorus, the lyrics have been parceled out to different characters so that each sung line functions as a line of dialogue. The sweet-tempered feckless young swain, Freddy Eynsford-Hill (Jim Stanek), begins falling for Eliza (Kate Fry). The linguistics professor Henry Higgins (Michael Cumpsty) reacts with smug reserve and ill-concealed glee as his experiment in behavioral control has its first public airing. His friend, Colonel Pickering (Simon Jones), becomes overwrought with excitement and concern. 
 And Henry's mother (Jane Connell), whose box everyone eventually gathers in, grows more and more irritated at her son for bringing a mere flower girl to an important social event and turning what was supposed to be a pleasant and relaxing day at the races into a trial. In conventional stagings, when the chorus sings, the lyrics ''Pulses rushing! Faces flushing! Heartbeats speed up'' refer to anticipation of the race that is about to begin.
 But here, everyone in the box is not only waiting for the race to begin but also feeling uptight socially in some way. And when Mrs. Higgins finishes the verse, singing, ''I have never been so keyed up!,'' there is a moment of comedy and character revelation. It isn't flashy, but it's a new and theatrically rewarding twist on a familiar scene. 
 ''What is Ascot?'' Mr. Griffin said. ''It's a scene with a famous visual stroke that you can't do at all on this scale. But our thing is not just to make something smaller. It's about what would be fun about the piece if we didn't have the history of it?''
 Reducing the size of a musical makes it more manageable physically and economically, of course, and allows it to be seen in theaters where it would otherwise be impossible. In the 360-seat Berlind, the McCarter is mounting ''My Fair Lady'' for $600,000, a pittance compared with what a full-blown extravaganza might cost. (In July it will be in the modest-size auditorium of the Hartford Stage.) You can almost hear the sniffing sounds of hungry commercial producers who are hoping the show satisfies an audience as well as it does a pocketbook.

Boiling Down to the Essence
 Its other potential advantages are a little subtler, and those are the ones Mr. Griffin and Mr. Murray have concentrated on. Mainly that what you don't get in a big musical in a big auditorium is a sense of intimacy with the characters or a nuanced view of their relationships, so the two men inverted what Lerner, Loewe and Hart did. 
 Instead of building around the scenes of posh extravagance, grandeur and musical frivolity -- that is, Ascot, the ball and Alfie Doolittle's Covent Garden frolics, ''With a Little Bit of Luck'' and ''Get Me to the Church on Time'' -- and linking them with the book scenes and smaller songs set in Henry's study, Mr. Griffin and Mr. Murray did the opposite. Their version is built around the study scenes, which they honed to a polish, with Ascot and the other big numbers refocused on the characters within them. It is an approach that the actors have felt keenly, making them think about making the music and the dialogue feed on each other.
 ''In rehearsal Gary always has both scripts with him, 'Pygmalion' and 'My Fair Lady,' '' Ms. Fry said. ''He's always going back to them. Clearly, or at least it seems to me, his top priority is to be completely true to the richness of the text. So one of the goals is not to make the songs five-minute diversions from the text, but extensions of scenes. And that doesn't only inform how you sing, but how you play the scene, because in order to rationalize any kind of song you have to be in some sort of heightened emotional state.''
 Mr. Cumpsty, who is not known as a musical-theater actor but who recently appeared nonetheless in ''42nd Street'' on Broadway, said he didn't at all miss the spectacle.
 ''I had all the sequins and bugle beads I needed on Broadway,'' he said. ''But having done mostly dramas, I would say that Gary, as an actor's director, is one of the most skilled I've ever worked with. He gives you a lot of space and then comes in and just nudges you in terms of action or intention or whatever. And to be doing a musical with someone who is so extremely precise about the text is fascinating.''
 And Mr. Jones, though the colonel in this production, played Henry in a fully inflated version of ''My Fair Lady'' at the Paper Mill Playhouse a dozen years ago, and said that making the show smaller made the actors bigger. 
 ''What's interesting is that when you get rid of the chorus, you remove a whole row of yes men,'' he said. ''So you have to justify yourself to the audience. You can say any old rubbish to a chorus and they've been trained to nod their heads, whether or not you're making any sense at all. But in this show you've really got to put it across.''
 One result of all this is that in the end, unlike most versions of ''My Fair Lady,'' which lean toward satisfying romantic closure, this one leaves it uncertain how Henry and Eliza resolve their feelings for each other. Anything might happen after the curtain; she might even decide to marry Freddy. This really is closer to the ending for ''Pygmalion,'' though Shaw was adamant that Eliza and Henry would never end up together.
 ''The idea,'' Mr. Murray said, looking as though he were mentally crossing his fingers, ''is that instead of being a sheer emotional high, it has a dramatic entertainment value as well.''

Wandering Into a Career
 Mr. Griffin, who was born in St. Louis and grew up in Rockford, Ill., wanted to be in journalism, which is what he began studying at the University at Wisconsin-Eau Claire, ''wandering into the theater,'' he said, and beginning to direct after he saw the work of the emerging Steppenwolf Theater Company in Chicago in the late 1970's. Learning that some members of that troupe had gone to Illinois State University, he enrolled there for graduate school, and eventually returned to Chicago to begin his career.
 Mr. Murray nearly vanished into technology. He grew up in El Paso, Tex., and traveled north for college, to Northwestern University in Evanston, Ill., where his double major was music and computer science. He considered going into opera as a vocal coach, then gave up music for a while and worked as an artificial-intelligence programmer, though finally it didn't take and, as he put it, ''I migrated back.''
 The two met when Mr. Griffin had just taken over as the artistic director of the Drury Lane Theater in Oakbrook Terrace, Ill., and Mr. Murray was called in as an emergency replacement for a music director who had quit. That was in 1994, and they've been staging musicals together since.
 They don't like to think of themselves as miniaturists, which in any case would not be entirely accurate. At the Drury Lane they presented largely standard stagings of traditional musicals like ''West Side Story'' and ''City of Angels.'' Among many other projects, they staged, in 1999, with the help of Stephen Sondheim, the first production of Mr. Sondheim's early musical ''Saturday Night,'' with the Pegasus Players, a small Chicago troupe. 
 Mr. Griffin (whose ''New Moon'' had a total of 46 singers and dancers onstage) will direct a new musical based on the Alice Walker novel ''The Color Purple,'' at the Alliance Theater in Atlanta this fall. In addition to other larger works, Mr. Murray was the musical director for the national tour of ''Parade.''
 But like sculptors whose hobby is building intricate model ships and bottling them, these men have developed a subspecialty of making musicals small. They collaborated on two Sondheim musicals, ''Pacific Overtures'' and ''Sunday in the Park With George,'' which were presented at the Chicago Shakespeare Theater, each production carving its peculiar performance space out of a tiny top-floor auditorium. Originally, those shows were elaborately presented in proscenium theaters. But Mr. Griffin and Mr. Murray staged ''Pacific Overtures,'' about the opening of Japan to the West, on a square wooden platform surrounded by the audience. 
 ''We liked the idea of the stage as a floating island,'' Mr. Griffin said.
 Even more daringly, ''Sunday,'' partly about the creation of a painting by Georges Seurat, and hence about perspective, was presented in its entirety on a slender runway with the audience on either side.
 ''Maybe it was just mischievous on our part,'' Mr. Griffin said. ''But Tom and I asked ourselves: 'Does that show really have to have a proscenium? Could it be you could tell that story if you didn't have the backdrop? Is there a way that perspective has a larger meaning than what the play says it means?' ''
 Both men say their strength is in how closely they work together, and you can see it in the rehearsal room. They check with each other constantly, often with just a nod or a gesture agreeing to adjust a dramatic beat or a musical phrase.
 Mr. Murray speaks about how watching Mr. Griffin work with actors on a script has helped him in coaching singers, and has allowed him to see that in a well-conceived and well-written musical, when the actor has nailed the character, the character will more easily find the musicality in the songs. 
 ''In giving the actors something to act and play through the songs, he's doing my job for me in a way,'' Mr. Murray said, ''because often the voice will respond to that kind of direction.''

An Earlier 'Lady'
 Mr. Griffin, for his part, says he considers lyrics to be lines of dialogue and melodic phrasing to be elements of character. ''Our interest over the years has been to make music, book and lyric seamless,'' he said. ''They're not departmentalized in how we think about the show, or how we speak about the show.'' 
 It helps, Mr. Murray said, that they have done so many shows together. And it helps even more, he said, that this is their second pass at ''My Fair Lady.'' Two years ago they staged it at the Court Theater, a professional company affiliated with the University of Chicago. That production evolved from an unsatisfying but instructive workshop of the show that had only five characters: Eliza, Freddy, Henry, Pickering and Alfie. (The two-piano orchestration was done in the 1950's by Trude Rittman, who was best known as a choreographer but who was asked by Loewe to make the arrangement. If it hadn't existed, Mr. Murray said, he would have done his own arrangement, ''with piano, bass, harp and woodwind or cello or something.'')
 For the current production, Mr. Griffin and Mr. Murray have made slight text changes, reinstating a character (Mrs. Hopkins, a friend of Alfie) though not adding an actor. (Brenda Martindale, who plays Freddy's mother, doubles in the part.) The set has also been modified slightly to accommodate the Berlind, which is a bit larger than the Court. The set has two tiers, an upstairs platform with a balustrade, connected to the stage floor by a spiral staircase.
 But the biggest difference is in the cast. Only Ms. Fry, as Eliza, is repeating her role.
 ''To be honest, it was a little daunting at first,'' Mr. Griffin said of taking on a work that is such a favorite and so keenly stamped on the public mind. ''People have so many expectations of this show. What I hope happens, and what Tom and I talk about a lot, is that even though you know you're not going to see the production values -- you walk into the theater and see the stage and the set and you know that's not going to happen -- what might be wonderful is that you'll discover more about the cleverness of the book and how smart the lyric writing is.''

Loverly
 ''My Fair Lady'' will run through June 27 in the Berlind Theater of the McCarter Theater Center, 91 University Place, Princeton, N.J. Performances are Tuesdays through Fridays at 7:30 p.m.; Saturdays at 4 and 8:30 p.m.; Sundays at 2:30 and 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $39 to $50. Information: (609) 258-2787.

An article in Weekend on Friday about a miniature production of ''My Fair Lady'' at the McCarter Theater Center in Princeton, N.J., misspelled the surname of the arranger of the 1950's two-piano orchestration of the musical and misstated her specialty. She is Trude Rittmann, not Rittman, and she was best known as a choral and dance music arranger, not as a choreographer.

HEADLINE: Constitutional Court Reinstates South Korea's Impeached President

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Friday, May 14 

 BODY:
South Korea's nine-member Constitutional Court ruled Friday to dismiss the impeachment case against President Roh Moo Hyun, restoring full powers to the president, in a case that had tested the nation's fledgling democracy.
 The ruling ended a crisis for South Korea, a major American ally and one of Asia's most dynamic economies, that began March 12, when the National Assembly unexpectedly approved a bill to impeach Mr. Roh on minor election law violations. A month later, voters punished conservative parliamentary candidates and tripled the seats of the Uri Party, a new liberal coalition that backs Mr. Roh, giving it a slim majority in the one-chamber National Assembly. 
 During Mr. Roh's two months of political limbo, presidential powers were exercised by the prime minister, Goh Kun. Mr. Roh resumed power immediately after the ruling. 
 This new political lease of life, coupled with control of the National Assembly, is expected to allow Mr. Roh to pursue a more activist agenda: to move the capital from Seoul to the nation's center, to soften the National Security Law which brands North Korea as ''the enemy,'' to strengthen antitrust laws against the chaebols, or conglomerates, and to place more distance in the close relationship with the United States.
 In a turn of the generational wheel, last month's vote elected a younger, more liberal National Assembly, where few have personal memories of the Korean War. In polls, majorities of Uri Party legislators have identified themselves as ''progressives,'' and have said South Korea's relations with China are more important than ties with the United States.
 Now, Mr. Roh must decide what to do about his promise to send 3,200 more troops to Iraq this summer, which would make the South Korean contingent the third largest, after the American and British.
 ''The No.1 issue for Roh Moo Hyun is Iraq,'' Richard C. Holbrooke, chairman of the Asia Society, said Thursday after meetings here with Mr. Roh's aides. ''They don't want Roh's rebirth screwed up by Iraq.''
 South Korea already has 450 military medics and engineers in Iraq. Last February, over angry public protests, the National Assembly voted to approve the deployment. Now, some Uri Party legislators are calling for a new authorizing vote. 
 On Tuesday, Uri Party members elected Chun Jung Bae, a former human rights lawyer, as their floor leader. Mr. Chun has floated the idea of sending money instead of troops.
 Further to the left, the Democratic Labor Party, now the third force in the National Assembly, is trying to organize legislators to block the troop dispatch. It wants the United States to withdraw its 37,000 troops from South Korea, and wants to abolish the National Security Law, which penalizes Communist activities here.
 The impeachment ended the legislative careers of four conservative leaders of the drive, and reduced the main pro-impeachment party, the Millennium Democrats, to fourth place. But the Grand National Party, a bulwark of traditional conservatism, still controls 40 percent of the seats, enough to block legislation on national security issues.
 ''The principle of the nation's plan to dispatch troops to Iraq, once approved by the National Assembly, must be kept,'' Park Geun Hye, the party's leader, said Monday.
 Many South Koreans say they hope Mr. Roh will work more smoothly with the National Assembly to address economic worries. In recent days, South Korea's stock market was buffeted by the news that China, the country's largest trading partner, is trying to curb its growth, that the United States may raise interest rates and that oil prices have hit $40 a barrel.

HEADLINE: Undaunted Arctic Couriers, Coming In With the Veggies

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

DATELINE: RESOLUTE BAY, Nunavut 

 BODY:
Takeoff is delayed for several minutes when the Global Positioning System locks up, apparently from the cold. Once the plane is airborne, the terrain below is a white swirling desert, sculptured of snow and ice. Then a sudden fog settles in.
 ''It's pretty fuzzy today, not a lot of definition,'' Troy McKerral, captain of the DHC-6 Twin Otter, says matter-of-factly. ''It's not a whiteout, but it makes it difficult to pick up any specific spots or places.'' 
 The complications are not nearly enough to abort the flight to resupply a lead and zinc mine on Little Cornwallis Island, an otherwise uninhabited ice-encased landmass more than 600 miles north of the Arctic Circle, and even farther from the nearest tree. 
 For Captain McKerral and his co-pilot, Erin McEvoy, and other Arctic fliers like them, it is just another day at the office. 
 For a living they land on trackless floating ice or short gravel runways, sometimes made shorter by a herd of caribou. Their landings are usually uneventful, unless the skis attached to the underbelly of their craft break through the ice, as they are increasingly wont to do with global warming. Then there is the occasional polar bear who lurks around the hangar.
 The pilots buzz through steep foggy fjords to deliver the mail, fresh food and medical supplies to remote Inuit communities. They take explorers and scientific expeditions to the North Pole and medevac women in labor to the area's few hospitals. Basically, they keep Canada whole.
 More than a third of Canada is Arctic wilderness, and the Arctic pilots are vital to the development of the icy north. They are the modern equivalent of the country's fabled rough-and-tumble ''bush pilots,'' men who returned from World War I with enough gumption in their hearts and bile in their bellies to explore and chart the vast territory early last century. 
 ''When we go on the glaciers, we depend on them to bring us everything for our stays of two, three or four weeks,'' said Jocelyne Bourgeois, a government glacierologist studying global warming in the Arctic. ''And they are the ones who come back to get us.''
 Remote as it is, the Arctic is an area of rapid social and economic development. The dominant Inuit population has evolved in just two generations from migratory hunters dependent on dogs to get around to a more or less modern lifestyle in rural communities where children learn on computers and adults buy food at supermarkets and motor about on snowmobiles, and tourism, mining and transport services generate jobs.
 Such a world would be unthinkable without the pilots flying their Twin Otters, Dash-8's and Douglas DC-3's over vast frozen areas without roads. ''Everybody has something that makes them feel good,'' Mr. McKerral said. ''Mine is bringing people a few extra veggies that day.''
 Mr. McKerral, 41, was born in Edmonton but has spent the better part of his life in the great white north. His father was also an Arctic pilot. He met his wife, a registered nurse, in the Arctic town of Inuvik. Both his own sons were born there. He says the simple northern life is fine by him.
 ''I like the remoteness,'' he said. ''It's unspoiled and, I mean, it's the last frontier. If I take a day trip into a city, I look forward to leaving. Bad drivers keep trying to run me off the road.''
 When Mr. McKerral is not flying he is living in an eight-room crew house with other pilots and flight personnel from Kenn Borek Air Ltd. , who rotate here for a few weeks at a time before heading home for a few weeks in the south.
 The crew house is reminiscent of a college dormitory, and everyone shares the cooking and cleaning chores. The kitchen is decorated with aviation maps and the cupboards are filled with jars of peanut butter, cans of jellied cranberry sauce, and packages of Kraft pizza and Shake 'n Bake. There is a frozen narwhal whale steak in the freezer, a gift from a grateful passenger.
 Part of a plane fuselage sticks out of the ice outside the kitchen window, a vivid reminder of the potential dangers of the job. Resolute Bay is virtually a graveyard of old planes, ranging from a Fairchild F-27 that crashed in the 1970's to an Avro Lancaster World War II bomber converted to deliver mail in the 1950's, before it met an untimely end.
 There is a helicopter fuselage on the ground, as well as the tail of a Douglas DC-3 poking out of the ice like a grave marker. Much of the wreckage can be seen by pilots and passengers while landing here.
 Still, the pilots insist that the grave danger of flying in these parts is now a thing of the past. The introduction of gas turbine engines in the 1960's and of antifreezing additives to fuel in the 1970's made the planes much more reliable. Global positioning revolutionized navigation in the late 1980's.
 The Arctic pilots today are heavily regulated, and employers carefully screen fliers with psychological tests to keep out the wilder crowd that flew around these parts in the early days. The fliers privately talk about bending some rules, like buzzing at low altitudes over remote national parks, flying overweight with extra fuel for long distances, and flying with G.P.S. systems not certified by the government.
 ''G.P.S. has taken the romance right out of flying because it's made it so easy,'' said John Downey, 55, an experienced Arctic pilot who flies out of Iqaluit, while waiting between flights in his hanger office.
 But he quickly contradicted himself, while sipping from his cup of coffee. ''It's still exciting to land on a piece of ground with no tracks,'' he said. ''Nobody has been there.''

HEADLINE: What Price Summer?

BYLINE: By JULIA LAWLOR

 BODY:
FORGET the old saw about early birds. When it comes to summer rentals these days, from New York's fashionable Hamptons to the family-oriented beach towns of the Outer Banks, it's a procrastinator's market. Real estate brokers blame everything from the Web (it lets people see which houses have really already been rented) to the economy and the continuing news from Iraq for the shift. ''The world is kind of upside down,'' said Jerry Grass, a real estate broker from Lake Orion, Mich., who owns a vacation property on the Upper Peninsula. ''People are kind of feeling their way.''
 Just ask Kristina Taylor and her husband, David, who have rented a house on Cape Cod for two weeks in August since 1980. Usually their plans are set by March, but this year the Taylors, who live in Ann Arbor, Mich., waited until early May to book. They found a bayside contemporary cape in Wellfleet, Mass., with four bedrooms and two bathrooms. And then knocked $300 a week off the price, bringing it to $1,650 a week -- $50 less per week than they paid last year. ''I was pleasantly surprised,'' Ms. Taylor said. 
 This will be the fourth summer of relatively flat prices in many resorts around the country. In part, that's because of the rapid increase in vacation-home sales (according to the National Association of Realtors there were an estimated 445,000 second homes sold in the United States last year, up from 359,000 in 2001), taking many renters out of the market. Then there's the still-weak economy in many spots and a growing feeling among renters that they should be able to get a bargain. ''Every caller we get wants us to negotiate,'' said Sue Peters, rental manager for Cape Shores Real Estate in Wellfleet. ''It's getting old.''
 Of course, not everyone is scaling back this summer. In the Hamptons, where sticker shock is an art form, Denise Rich, the songwriter and Bill Clinton confidante, has rented out her Southampton estate, Swan's Way, for the season. Ms. Rich, who bought the house in 1999, had two bidders angling for her house and ultimately rented it out for a reported $530,000 for Memorial Day to Labor Day. It does have easy access to the Southampton heliport, plus a 7-bedroom, 11-bath main house; a 4-bedroom, 5-bath guesthouse; tennis courts; indoor and outdoor pools; and Cooper's Neck Pond waterfront. And come fall, it will be for sale. Asking price: $23 million.
 Here, with the unofficial start of summer just two weeks away, a look at the state of vacation rentals in 10 popular resort areas around the country, from east to west.

Mount Desert Island, Me.
 If you're looking for oceanfront on this island off the northern coast of Maine, you're out of luck. According to Danielle Davis, owner of the Davis Agency in Southwest Harbor, all of the agency's waterfront homes have been snapped up. But rentals of other properties, ranging from cabins in the woods to village homes and old-fashioned lakefront farmhouses, are slightly down from last year. Prices for a four-bedroom house in a village are $1,500 to $1,800 a week; ocean and lakefront houses range from $2,000 to $10,000 a week. Most rentals are for two weeks.
 The big attraction is the 47,000-acre Acadia National Park, with its miles of hiking and biking trails and views from the top of Cadillac Mountain. Along the rugged coast of the island, which is about a five-hour drive from Boston, are the quaint villages of Bar Harbor, Tremont, Southwest Harbor and Northeast Harbor. 
 ''The beauty of this area is that you can swim, canoe, kayak, walk along the shore and climb over the rocks,'' Ms. Davis said. ''There's a lot to do, and it's free.'' 
 One factor that's helping hold prices down: A growing number of houses for rent. Taxes in many towns have risen over the last few years, with taxes on waterfront properties in some places doubling. Ms. Davis said her agency has recently been getting about 25 new properties a year to rent; last year, 40 new places came on the market. ''People probably need to rent their houses out to pay the expenses,'' she said.

Wellfleet, Mass.
 The Taylors aren't the only procrastinators looking for a bargain in this historic Cape Cod town. Though Wellfleet's big houses are usually booked up by May, this year many are still available, said Ms. Peters of Cape Shores Real Estate. Instead, renters seem to be flocking to smaller two-bedroom houses that rent for about $1,000 a week. In another trend, many vacationers are opting for one week instead of two. 
 No one is ever very far from the water in Wellfleet, since the town sits between the Atlantic Ocean and Wellfleet Harbor, a distance of only about three miles at the widest point. Housing ranges from classic New England saltboxes and capes to Greek Revival and contemporary houses. In addition to beaches, there are many freshwater ponds, which make the area popular with families. Sixty-one percent of the town is taken up by the Cape Cod National Seashore, a protected area for hiking, biking and nature walks through the marshes, sand dunes and forests of pitch pine and scrub oak.
 A house with three bedrooms on the waterfront typically goes for $5,000 a week. Ms. Peters recently rented a four-bedroom, two-bath house that usually costs $1,850 a week in August for $1,500. And with summer approaching, the discounts may get even steeper, she said. ''It's 'Let's Make a Deal' time.''

The Hamptons, N.Y.
 In the Hamptons, the typical rental -- four bedrooms and a pool -- starts at $40,000 for the season. Though Ms. Rich got her asking price, not everyone has been so lucky. Gene Rindfuss, a sales associate at Coldwell Banker Dunes View Properties in Westhampton, said there are still lots of properties available, including a five-bedroom modern oceanfront house for $125,000, and a five-bedroom, four-bath new house near the village with a pool and tennis courts for $50,000. ''Owners are calling and getting panicky,'' he said. (But they're not cutting prices -- yet.)
 Unlike rentals in many seashore resorts, those in the Hamptons, with fine restaurants, beautiful beaches, lively bars and opportunities for celebrity spotting, tend to be for the season (or, increasingly, for at least a month). The summer rentals market lives and dies by Wall Street. ''When bonuses were strong, rentals were strong,'' said Gina Decker, managing broker of Century 21 Agawam Albertson in Southampton. Last summer, the stock market's woes and rainy weather in May and June had demand and prices down; this year, agents expect prices to stay about the same. Ms. Decker said that at her agency the season is ''off to a steady but slow start.''
 As elsewhere, one of the biggest changes in the area has been the rental season's kickoff. Traditionally, New Yorkers had their Hamptons places already rented by Presidents' Day. Now, Mr. Rindfuss said, ''they wait until the last minute. It's already mid-May and people are looking to rent Memorial Day through Labor Day.''
 Janet Hummel, manager of the Corcoran Group in Bridgehampton, said that rentals in the areas she handles, including Sagaponack and Wainscott, were running ahead of last year, though there were some properties in the middle range -- about $50,000 -- still left. One is a four-bedroom, four-bath traditional-style house with farm views on an acre with a heated pool and three fireplaces. The owner of the house was offered $35,000 for it this week and turned it down, Ms. Hummel said. ''Last year we had a lot more bottom feeders coming out in May, making a bunch of offers and grabbing whoever gave them the best price,'' she said. ''This year you still have the bottom feeders offering landlords $20,000 less, but the landlords aren't discounting.''

Ocean City, N.J.
 On the Jersey Shore, Michael Monihan, president and co-owner of Monihan Realty in Ocean City, figures gas prices near $2 a gallon could be good for business. Most vacationers are from the Philadelphia area, a one- or two-hour drive away. ''When gas prices are high, most people stay closer to home,'' he said. 
 Ocean City, a quintessential Jersey Shore town, is on a seven-and-a-half-mile-long barrier island about a 20-minute drive south of Atlantic City. It was founded 125 years ago by Methodist ministers as a summer retreat. There is a boardwalk with amusement rides, salt-water taffy stores and fudge shops, but no bars or restaurants that serve alcohol, making it a popular destination for families.
 Mr. Monihan said houses for prime-time weeks -- from mid-July through the third week of August -- are going fast. A typical rental is a three- or four-bedroom unit in a duplex, with rents ranging from $1,500 to $2,300 a week, depending on distance from the beach. (Among the most sought-after blocks are in the so-called Gold Coast, along the beach from 23rd to 29th Streets.) Renters can expect prices to stay about the same this summer because the stock of houses keeps growing. Many older one-family houses are being torn down and replaced with modern duplexes that are more attractive to renters, said Steve Booth, a real estate broker and manager of Prudential Fox & Roach Realtors in Ocean City. 
 Mr. Booth said that his agency's rentals were down 7 percent the first four months of this year compared with the same period last year, though he believed things would catch up by the end of the summer. And here, too, renters are booking later, tracking their houses on the Web without putting any money down. ''Now, instead of booking by the first week in February, they can wait until the last week in June,'' he said.

Duck, N.C.
 North Carolina's Outer Banks stretch for almost 100 miles, from the Virginia border to Ocracoke and Portsmouth Islands to the south. It's a once-sleepy area of sand dunes and fishing towns, now turned into a summer destination for more than 7 million annual visitors. There are no boardwalks, amusement parks, nightclubs or fine dining. Those who can tear their sun-tanned bodies away from the dune-fringed beaches can go hang-gliding, parasailing, kayaking and fishing. 
 Explosive growth in recent years means prices haven't gone up since 2000. Indeed, according to Beth Dobney, a sales consultant for Coldwell Banker Seaside Realty in Kitty Hawk, N.C., over the last three years the number of new houses being built in the area has grown by 25 percent annually. Tim Cafferty, president and general manager of ResortQuest Outer Banks, in Duck on the north end of the banks, agreed. ''We may be seeing a dilution of the market,'' he said. ''There may be just as many people, but more properties to choose from.''
 The biggest bargains are older houses, local agents say, because many renters prefer new places -- Ms. Dobney called them ''mini-resorts'' -- with amenities like pools, hot tubs, game rooms and even high-speed Internet access. Air-conditioning is now a must, according to Mr. Cafferty. For all that, renters can expect to pay $3,000 a week for a five-bedroom, four-bath house several hundred feet from the beach. On the high end, a 9-bedroom, 10-bath oceanfront house that sleeps 26 goes for $15,000 a week. Typically, two or more families will share the same house. ''We are family-reunion oriented,'' Mr. Cafferty said.

Gulf Shores, Ala.
 Though this spot, on a 38-mile-long island off the gulf coast of Alabama and Florida, boasts fine, white-sand beaches and deep blue waters, it has never been as popular -- or as pricey -- as better-known places like Kiawah Island, S.C., or Destin, Fla., just a short trip down the Florida panhandle. This summer, bookings are up compared with last year, and so are rental prices, by about 5 percent, according to David Goodman, marketing manager for Meyer Real Estate in Gulf Shores. 
 Much of the development in the Gulf Shores and nearby Orange Beach sections of the island has come in the last 15 years, and rentals in those areas tend to be in 13- or 14-story high-rises. A three-bedroom, two-bath gulf-front condominium rents for $1,575 a week in the peak month of July, and drops to $900 a week just after Labor Day. In Fort Morgan, at the western end, there are more single-family houses, including some in newly developed communities like Martinique on the Gulf, a West Indies-style development with its own beach and tennis clubs.

St. Ignace, Mich.
 This harbor town on Michigan's Upper Peninsula is the eastern gateway to the peninsula, connected by a five-mile-long suspension bridge from Mackinac City over the Straits of Mackinac. Most people who vacation here are drawn from Detroit, about 300 miles to the south, or Chicago, more than a six-hour drive away. 
 So far, waterfront properties (you can be on either Lake Michigan to the west or Lake Huron to the east) have been renting briskly, according to Cheryl Schlehuber, a broker and the owner of Mackinac Properties in St. Ignace. But then prices for its waterfront are modest compared with much of the country, with rents ranging from $700 to $1,300 a week for a two- or three-bedroom, one-bath cottage. ''We're very affordable for the average family,'' Ms. Schlehuber said.
 Mr. Grass, the Michigan real estate broker, has been renting out his two-bedroom, two-bath condo overlooking Lake Huron for the last three years. So far, he has booked 60 percent to 70 percent of the weeks available, slightly behind last year. And though he has raised the price a total of 10 percent since he started renting out his place, this year there will be no increase. ''The economy is coming back,'' he said, ''but it's not back yet.''

Bigfork, Mont.
 Last year, this town on the northeast corner of Flathead Lake managed to escape massive forest fires that decimated 300,000 largely uninhabited acres north of the Flathead Valley, a big bowl dominated by the 30-mile-long, 16-mile-wide lake. Now, the fires are out, but that hasn't kept some would-be renters from worrying, said Tom Vitek, who with his wife, Jane, owns Somers Bay Log Cabin Lodging in Bigfork. The couple's seven log cabins rent weekly for between $900 and $1,600, or by the night. So far, this is the slowest season the Viteks have seen since they bought the resort seven years ago. 
 Peter Burkett, owner of All Pro Rental in nearby Kalispell said bookings are a little slower this year compared with last. Prices range from $895 a week for a two-bedroom house to $3,500 a week for a house that sleeps 15. Visitors to the area can find everything from fine restaurants to wilderness hiking -- not to mention Glacier National Park just 30 miles away. And Flathead Lake is even warm enough to swim in, Mr. Burkett said. The only drawback: Beaches are gravel, not sand. 
 Will prices be discounted to lure more renters? ''We'll see how the summer goes,'' Mr. Vitek said.

San Diego
 The market may be slow elsewhere in the country, but by now, most oceanfront rentals in Mission Beach and Pacific Beach have been snapped up. The two communities sit a few miles apart, bordered by the Pacific Ocean and Mission Bay.
 The one bright spot for summer renters: After years of big rate increases in the late 90's, prices have stabilized, according to Greg Flaherty, president of Penny Realty in San Diego. A typical oceanfront three-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath two-story town house rents for $4,300 a week in July and August, dropping to $2,400 off season. An inland three-bedroom, two-bath house with a partial ocean view costs $2,600 a week in July and August, $2,100 in the off-season. 
 There is a boardwalk with amusement rides and games, including an old-fashioned wooden roller coaster, and a never-ending parade of joggers, cyclists and in-line skaters, some of whom delight in dressing up in outlandish costumes. Downtown San Diego is just a 10- to 15-minute drive away.
 Although most vacationers drive from Arizona or northern California, Mr. Flaherty said high gas prices did not seem to be keeping them away. ''It's a concern in the back of my mind,'' he said, ''but it hasn't hurt us yet.''

San Juan Island, Wash.
 In the 25 minutes it takes to drive from one end of San Juan Island to the other, there is not one traffic light. The speed limit never exceeds 45 miles per hour. Once off the ferry in Friday Harbor, the small-town gateway to this 26-mile-long, 14-mile-wide island between the mainland and Vancouver Island, you can kiss your Type A tendencies goodbye. ''Your whole lifestyle slows down,'' said WendyKay Gewiss, vacation rental manager for Windermere Vacation Rentals in Friday Harbor. 
 The market, on the other hand, has remained brisk. This year, people started booking as early as November, and some have put down deposits for the summer of 2005. And though Ms. Gewiss says her agency has more large houses in its rental pool this year, they are still going -- and prices are holding steady. The most coveted properties are on the northwest coast, ranging from $2,200 to $2,700 a week for a house that sleeps eight. Small one- or two-bedroom cottages are $1,000 to $1,300. Almost all houses are on the waterfront or have water views. 
 Because San Juan is in a ''rain shadow,'' it can be sunny and 10 degrees warmer even when it is raining 100 miles to the south in Seattle. Sailing, kayaking and biking are big, but with water temperatures hovering from 47 to 53 degrees year-round, most people leave their swimsuits behind. One of the most popular pastimes is killer whale watching, especially when sitting on the deck of an oceanfront house with a Gorgonzola-stuffed olive martini in hand and the sun sinking into the Pacific.

HEADLINE: THEATER GUIDE

 BODY:

A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.+ means discounted tickets were available at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights.++ means discounted tickets were available at the TKTS booth for last Friday night only.

Broadway

*+ ''ASSASSINS.'' This is what they always wanted, isn't it? A clear shot at the big time, where people would have to pay attention to them? More than a decade after they first surfaced to critical shudders and head-scratching, the unhappy have-nots of ''Assassins'' -- the glitteringly dark musical by Stephen Sondheim and John Weidman about Americans who dream of killing their country's presidents -- have finally made it to Broadway. So can these desperate people, whose greatest fear is of being thought small, actually expand in proportion to the lavish production they have been given? Oh boy, can they ever. Accompanied by a sumptuously full orchestra and portrayed by a cast that finds the magnetism in rage and resentment, the frightening title characters of ''Assassins'' are restating their demand to be noticed in this Roundabout Theater Company production. And under Joe Mantello's direction, they are doing so with an eloquence and an intensity that make a compelling case for a show once regarded as a mere curiosity as a major piece from a major composer (1:50). Studio 54, 254 West 54th Street, (212) 719-1300. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 2 p.m. Tickets: $36.25 to $91.25 (Ben Brantley).

''BOMBAY DREAMS.'' Colors don't come any juicier than those that saturate this $14 million musical about movie-love Bollywood-style. Scarcely a scene goes by that isn't splashed with gorgeous heaping helpings of oranges, golds, greens, purples, yellows and more shades of pink than even Estee Lauder had names for. Yet such is the perverse spell cast by this friendly, flat and finally unengaging tale of glamorous movie stars and lovable untouchables that everything seems to melt into one neutral blur before your eyes, like a monochromatic symphony in the key of beige. A R Rahman's score has a certain rhythmic infectiousness. And as a self-centered Bollywood screen siren, the deliciously superficial Ayesha Dharker helps turn the central production numbers into lively paeans to Bollywood kitsch. But under the direction of Steven Pimlott, this retooling of a hit from London feels trapped in a listless limbo between tipsy spoof and sober sincerity (2:30). Broadway Theater, 1681 Broadway, at 53rd Street, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays through Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets: $42.25 to $101.25 (Brantley).

+ ''CAROLINE, OR CHANGE.'' A carefully wrought, impeccably performed chamber opera from Tony Kushner (''Angels in America'') and Jeanine Tesori (''Thoroughly Modern Millie''), directed by George C. Wolfe. In temperament this sung-through show is much like its stoical, uncompromising title character (Tonya Pinkins), a black maid for a Southern Jewish family in 1963. A current of self-denial runs through ''Caroline,'' from a libretto that refuses to sentimentalize its heroine to its deliberately fragmented score that avoids anthems of uplift. The tone throughout is evenhanded, slightly distanced compassion as people of different classes are revealed as pawns of a corrupting economic structure. Ms. Pinkins, who has never been better, gives an intense, controlled and commanding performance. In ambition and achievement, ''Caroline'' handily tops this season's new musicals. But it is almost too good to be good (2:35). Eugene O'Neill Theater, 230 West 49th Street, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays at 7 p.m.; Wednesdays through Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets: $26 to $101 (Brantley).

*+ ''FROZEN.'' For a play centered on a serial murderer of little girls, Bryony Lavery's humane, intelligent drama is striking for its sustained aura of ordinariness. ''Frozen'' is indeed the story of the brutal killing of a child and its repercussions. Yet no trace of sensationalism colors Doug Hughes's beautifully acted, carefully considered production, which stars Swoosie Kurtz (as the child's mother), Brian F. O'Byrne (as the murderer) and Laila Robins (as an academic specializing in serial killers). No sinister, spine-tingling music or screams of terror and pain are heard. Instead, a contemplative quiet enfolds the stage. And the characters, who often speak in monologues, don't so much vent their intense emotions as betray them through involuntary eruptions that they quickly stifle. In the age of the Amber Alert and Megan's Law, ''Frozen'' brings a coolly discursive attitude to a hot-button subject. This is not to say it is in any way unfeeling (2:15). Circle in the Square, 1633 Broadway, at 50th Street, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays at 7 p.m.; Wednesdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Thursdays and Fridays at 8 p.m.; Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets: $85 (Brantley).

*+ ''JUMPERS.'' Acrobatics aren't just for athletes in this high-flying revival of Tom Stoppard's 1972 play. Though the show features an enthusiastic team of bouncing gymnasts, everyone in ''Jumpers'' jumps, in one way or another -- verbally, emotionally, morally. And with a cast headed by Simon Russell Beale, in a dazzling Broadway debut, such exertions turn this comic mystery of murder, marriage and metaphysics into one of the most entertaining exercise sessions available. Leaps of faith, back-flipping politics, somersaulting, self-inverting words and free-falling nervous breakdowns are all on offer in the restless, relativistic world of ''Jumpers.'' The director David Leveaux appropriately serves up a show that never seems to stop spinning, from its chic revolving set to the frantic, farcical movements of its characters. But at the same time, this luscious import from the Royal National Theater of Great Britain, which also stars the divine Essie Davis, finds a wounded, hungry heart beneath the razzle dazzle. A play often dismissed as too clever by half now registers clearly as a poignant acknowledgment of the limits of cleverness (2:30). Brooks Atkinson Theater, 256 West 47th Street, (212) 307-4100. Tuesdays through Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m.; Tickets: $60 to $95 (Brantley).

''A RAISIN IN THE SUN.'' Sean Combs's shadow precedes him in this seriously off-center revival of Lorraine Hansberry's epochal drama of an African-American family in Southside Chicago. Will the very 21st-century figure who is Mr. Combs (a k a P. Diddy), whose career has been a triumph of nerve over probability, be able to evoke a man of thwarted dreams from the mid-20th century? Unfortunately, while the opening, engagingly boyish moments of his performance have promise, his Walter Lee Younger never appears to change, happy or sad, drunk or sober. His evenly measured words and debating team captain's gestures remain pretty much the same. And while Audra McDonald and Phylicia Rashad do sterling work as Walter Lee's wife and mother, much of Kenny Leon's production exudes the single-note perkiness of a sitcom. Instead of contrasting the forces of an older, God-fearing generation with a fresh revolutionary spirit (embodied by Walter Lee and his sister, played by Sanaa Lathan), the show becomes an unwitting counterpoint of mature and callow acting styles (2:30). Royale Theater, 242 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays through Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets: $26.25 to $91.25 (Brantley).

Off Broadway

+ ''THE DISTANCE FROM HERE.'' The poetic, brooding wistfulness of the title doesn't quite capture the essence of Neil LaBute's play. A more appropriate name for this less than subtle study of hope-starved American youth might be ''The Crass Menagerie.'' The play begins with two loutish lads hurling themselves against a railing in a zoo to stir up the chimpanzees within, and it's Mr. LaBute's grim joke that just who the real animals are is not an easy call. In his scripts for films like ''In the Company of Men,'' as well as plays like the harrowing ''Bash,'' this highly accomplished artist of misanthropy has reveled in uncovering the feral snarl beneath the bland smiles of middle-class Americans. ''The Distance From Here,'' directed by Michael Greif and featuring the Oscar-winning actress Anna Paquin, focuses on a social underclass of born losers. And despite the best efforts of the intense young cast, there aren't many suprises within all the apathy and anger (1:45) The Duke on 42nd Street, 229 West 42nd Street, (212)239-6200. Mondays and Tuesdays at 7 p.m.; Wednesdays through Fridays at 8 p.m.; Saturdays at 2:30 and 8 p.m. Tickets: $50 (Brantley).

+ ''ENGAGED.'' Everything looks decorous and refined in the Victorian world of ''Engaged.'' This being a play by W. S. Gilbert, the decorous and the refined provide a light cover for strategic lunacy. Everything looks delightful in the Theater for a New Audience production, directed by Doug Hughes; the problems lie almost everywhere else. The outcome is a heavy tramp through a play that needs to be an airy romp. Gilbert satirizes the gap between emotional proprieties and financial greed, and he parodies the English fad for the rustic. Marriages and engagements are made and unmade at top speed, and there are moments of antic madness. To be staged effectively, ''Engaged'' should be cut. Most important, it must be directed with musical lightness and speed. Here speeches turn into exposition, when every fiber of one's being calls out: ''No! This is supposed to sound as if the character is bursting into song'' (2:05). Lucille Lortel Theater, 121 Christopher Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays through Fridays at 8 p.m.; Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets: $60 (Margo Jefferson).

''GUINEA PIG SOLO.'' The mesmerizing John Ortiz scales new heights of calisthenic despair in Brett C. Leonard's portrait of a harrowed veteran of the war in Iraq, trying to stay sane in New York City. As a lost man with a short fuse, Mr. Ortiz leaps and bounds like an anguished Douglas Fairbanks. The play is a latter-day reworking of ''Woyzeck,'' Georg Buchner's great fragmented drama from the 1830's. But people in Mr. Leonard's world talk a lot more than than Buchner's characters do. This is not an asset. No matter how frenetically delivered, the dialogue and especially the monologues feel cumbersomely overstated, like messages carved in stone. On the other hand, Ian Belton's staging and Mr. Ortiz's performance are both precise and exhaustingly energetic, with some resonant repeated images. A production of the LAByrinth Theater Company, which specializes in lives of desperation that are anything but quiet (2:10). Public Theater/Shiva Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays through Fridays at 8 p.m.; Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 2 p.m. Tickets: $45 (Brantley).

*+ ''THE NORMAL HEART.'' This absorbing revival allows you to register some of the gale force with which Larry Kramer's benchmark play hit New York in 1985. In portraying the early impact of AIDS, Mr. Kramer lashed out at the institutions and individuals of power he felt had looked away from a crisis-in-the-making, including The New York Times and Mayor Edward I. Koch. Dramas that run high fevers of social outrage tend to cool off over time, of course. But there is nothing quaint about this production, directed by David Esbjornson and starring Raul Esparza as Ned Weeks, the truth-telling gay writer who is Mr. Kramer's alter ego. At its best, this production has the fraught urgency of a dispatch from a war zone. And it illuminates a poignant, quieter pattern of a longing to connect in a world that keeps building new walls among people (2:45). Public Theater/Anspacher Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays through Fridays at 8 p.m.; Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 2 and 7 p.m. Tickets: $55 (Brantley).

Last Chance

* ''WELL.'' Lisa Kron made her reputation as a monologuist of wry, rueful wit and thorny eloquence. With this remarkable memory play about her mother, she has constructed a theatrical world that keeps interrupting and undermining the polished self-containment of the stand-up memoir. ''Well'' systematically dismantles the armor Ms. Kron wears as a performer, from her self-consciously self-conscious stage persona to her carefully barbed phrasing. To do so, it enlists a full-dress, expertly assembled production, directed by Leigh Silverman, and a cast that features the wonderful Jayne Houdyshell as Ms. Kron's mother, who eventually takes over the play. ''Well,'' Ms. Kron tells her audience, is about illness and racial integration, and it slyly finds the connection between such seemingly disparate subjects. And while accepting that it is impossible to know someone else completely, ''Well'' paradoxically leads you into believing that you know Ms. Kron's mother very well indeed. A play of remarkable generosity and humility (1:45). Public Theater/Martinson Hall, 425 Lafayette Street, East Village, (212) 239-6200. Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 2 and 7 p.m. Tickets: $50 (Brantley).

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Asia: Japan: Optimistic Outlook

BYLINE: By Todd Zaun (NYT)

 BODY:
Japan's two-year recovery appears to be on solid ground as a result of government efforts to tackle some of the worst of the country's economic troubles, according to John B. Taylor, left, the under secretary for international affairs in the United States Treasury Department. ''We learned a lot about what we think is a more sustainable recovery than has existed for a long time in Japan,'' Mr. Taylor said after meeting government officials and economists in Tokyo on Thursday. He praised Japan's progress in dealing with deflation and bad bank loans. Mr. Taylor said he was optimistic that Japan's recovery would continue because of recent indications that consumer demand is picking up. Todd Zaun (NYT)

HEADLINE: First Insiders Sold Their Shares Privately, Then Salesforce.com Filed to Go Public

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
THE right of investors to know when corporate insiders sell stock -- and at what price -- is a fundamental part of American securities law. When it turned out that Ken Lay, the former chairman of Enron, was using a loophole to sell shares secretly while he urged others to buy, Congress quickly changed the law.
 But one loophole still remains, and it is being used by Salesforce.com, a software company about to go public. 
 At first glance, this offering shows no selling of shares by insiders. But an investor who adds and compares numbers on different pages of the prospectus discovers that insiders have disposed of millions of shares since they bought them in 1999 and 2000. Were they sold years ago, or weeks ago? At what price? The prospectus has no answers. 
 When I asked Marc Benioff, the chief executive, what he did with the shares he used to own, he replied in an e-mail message that Securities and Exchange Commission rules barred him from talking. But no rules bar the company from amending its prospectus to give the facts.
 Salesforce.com leases software to corporate customers that lets them share data on their customers within different parts of the company. The customers get access to the software and their data through the Internet.
 The company spends little on research and development: 7 percent of revenue in the most recent year. It spends a lot more on marketing: 57 percent of revenue. The cost of actually providing its service to customers is only 18 percent of revenue. If it could ever slash marketing costs, it might be very profitable.
 When the company was founded in 1999, as the Internet bubble was expanding, the owners never thought they would have to wait this long to go public. In starting a company foundation, to which insiders have donated 221,030 shares, Salesforce.com gave it warrants whose terms assumed a successful public offering by early 2002 at the latest.
 Then the bubble burst and the rules changed. Suddenly investors wanted profits.
 Salesforce.com changed, too. In 2001 it walked away from a lease on expensive office space in San Francisco, recording a $7.7 million hit to earnings. In the fiscal year that began in February 2002, it cut back on advertising, but continued to hire salespeople. Mr. Benioff's salary for that year and the next was just $1, with no bonus or options.
 It worked. The company reported a $3.5 million profit in the year that ended this January, and it promptly filed to sell shares. That profit would have almost vanished had a recovering office market not allowed it to reverse part of that rental charge, and it would have vanished entirely had Mr. Benioff made a more normal salary. (The company does not say what he received before the bubble burst.) 
 But it was a profit, and with technology shares having recovered, the company hopes to get $7.50 to $8.50 a share, valuing it at as much as $868 million, or 10 times its revenue in the last year. Such a price would seem to assume continued rapid growth and the ability to sell to large companies that have so far resisted its salespeople.
 Given his $1 salary, one might think some stock sales by Mr. Benioff were necessary. A man does have to eat. But he has claimed he made more than $10 million as an early investor in Siebel Systems and more than that off options at Oracle, where he used to work. Even after deducting the $2.5 million he invested in Salesforce.com, that would seem to have left enough money to pay bills.
 If he sold shares, as opposed to giving them all away, that would indicate that he found the price attractive. But he won't say how many he sold, or when, or for how much.
 That information is clearly relevant. The S.E.C. should change its rules to make companies going public disclose the details of such insider selling.

HEADLINE: As Prices Rise, Russia Alters Oil Politics Toward U.S.

BYLINE: By ERIN E. ARVEDLUND

DATELINE: MOSCOW 

 BODY:
Almost three years after the Sept. 11 attacks, America is still seeking sources of energy besides the Middle East, and Russia has plenty of oil to sell.
 But after numerous meetings and high-level talks, the once-promising United States-Russia energy dialogue is sputtering, say government officials and foreign and Russian energy companies.
 Worse, multinationals like Exxon Mobil are losing ground in developing promising oil and gas projects in Russia. In January, Exxon Mobil lost its license to a significant concession in the Sakhalin Islands in Russia's Far East that it had not yet developed. 
 What happened? The arrest of Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the billionaire oil tycoon and founder of Yukos, was only the final blow. Before he was jailed, Mr. Khodorkovsky pushed for higher oil exports to the West and even pledged to build a pipeline to China, efforts that the Kremlin came to view as a threat to its power. [Mr. Khodorkovsky's latest plea to be released on bail was turned down this week by a Moscow City Court, the Reuters news agency said Wednesday.]
 But another factor looms: with global oil prices soaring, Russian producers are raking in profits, so the government no longer feels compelled to sell oil to America. [Crude oil for June delivery rose 31 cents, to $41.08 a barrel, in trading in New York on Thursday. ]
 A hoped-for pipeline from the Caspian Sea to Murmansk in far northern Russia, from which Russian oil companies could ship to the United States, will probably not be built. Instead, the Kremlin is negotiating to build a pipeline to Nakhodka, a port on the Sea of Japan, which will bring oil to East Asia; that project has $6 billion in financing promised from the Japanese government.
 The war in Iraq, meanwhile, has soured relations between the United States and Russia, which sided with France and Germany in opposing the conflict. 
 ''Something is definitely wrong with U.S.-Russia relations over the past three years, and the results of the energy dialogue are not impressive,'' says Timofei Bordachev, director of the Institute of Foreign and Defense Policies research group here.
 Peter Westin, an economist with Aton Bank, explained: ''The enthusiasm has waned, as high oil prices give Russia more leverage. Khodorkovsky also got his hands chopped off, and among many other things, that sends a signal to oil companies that they, too, should be careful.''
 In 2003, Exxon Mobil and ChevronTexaco declared their interest in buying into Russia's abundant oil reserves, and Total of France and the Royal Dutch/Shell Group have not been ruled out of the running, despite both companies' declarations to the contrary.
 But ever since BP's $6.15 billion deal for a stake in TNK, no other sizable deals have been signed between foreign and Russian oil majors.
 Russia's energy ministry is now revisiting some deals signed in the 1990's, like Exxon Mobil's Sakhalin-3 concession in the Sakhalin Islands off Japan in 1993. The ministry says that concession should be put out for new bidding. 
 ''I'm surprised there hasn't been more of an outcry,'' Glenn Waller, vice president for Russia at Exxon Mobil, said in an interview. The American Chamber of Commerce and the U.S.-Russia Business Council here have been writing letters of protest, he added. ''They see it as an issue of principle, not just an issue facing one or two companies.''
 No date has been set for a new tender of the concession. 
 But even Russian oil companies say the energy dialogue will be at a standstill unless more contacts develop between individual companies, even small- and medium-size energy concerns.
 ''The starter is there, but the engine's not running,'' Vagit Y. Alekperov, the founder of Lukoil, said in an interview in April. ''A lot happened at a high level, when German Gref and Don Evans were talking,'' he said, referring to Russia's economic development and trade minister and the American commerce secretary. ''They were the driving force. But this dialogue should not be only at the government level -- companies should continue it, and that's not happening.''
 Lukoil, which backed the suspended Murmansk pipeline, has emerged as one of the most aggressive sellers of oil to the United States. Last fall, it opened a chain of its red-and-white gas stations in the New York area, some of them bought from Getty in 2000.
 Still, Russia has largely abandoned production-sharing agreements with foreign oil companies, and record-high oil prices have offered Russia the luxury of not selling stakes in domestic majors.
 ''They've decided that given the improving economy, and higher ratings from bond agencies, that all of the former incentives they gave foreign companies to invest in Russia are no longer necessary,'' said A. Grant McCrea, partner in the litigation group of the law firm of Dewey Ballantine. Exxon Mobil will probably not be able to contest the lost license successfully in a Russian court, he added.
 ''I'd be surprised if there was an imminent foreign equity investment of a very large scale in the Russian oil business,'' said Robert Dudley, chief executive of TNK-BP, the product of one of the only successful mergers of Western and Russian oil concerns. BP took a stake in TNK in 2003 to acquire access to Russian oil. TNK-BP accounts for one of every five barrels of BP's output.
 On top of everything else, Kremlin politics have also altered the outlook for United States-Russia energy cooperation.
 Mr. Putin's landslide re-election in March gave him a mandate to shift gears: after spending his first term prodding growth in oil exports, Russia's president wants to tax the domestic oil sector heavily and diversify the economy away from energy.
 ''Putin's priority in his first term was establishing control over the country and rebuilding fiscal reserves,'' the chief strategist with Alfa Bank in Moscow, Christopher Weafer, said. ''The only way he could do that was pushing for recovery in oil production and exports. But that was only the first phase for the bigger picture. His agenda now is diversifying the economy.''
 ''Russia is good at playing the middle ground,'' he added. ''They played it with OPEC and oil prices and they played it with Russia-U.S. energy dialogue. It suited Putin's domestic agenda at the time. Now that's changed completely, and it suits him not to push ahead with investment in the oil sector.''
 Fiona Hill of the Brookings Institution in Washington concurs. ''Putin is reassessing his priorities,'' she said, ''and where he wants Russia to be on the global energy stage.''
 In the meantime, President Bush is likely to be consumed by his re-election campaign, which could delay any dialogue on energy.
 Still, American oil companies cannot afford to give up on Russian oil, said Julian Lee, an analyst at the Center for Global Energy Studies in London.
 ''Russia has become increasingly important for international oil companies generally,'' Mr. Lee said. ''It's one area of the world where oil producers believe there are still huge reserves left. And we're going to see companies trying to get hold of them in Russia one way or the other.''
