HEADLINE: Low Rates, High Expectations

BYLINE: By James Grant. 
James Grant is the editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer.

 BODY:
Inflation is returning to the American checkout counter under the unlikely sponsorship of the Federal Reserve. For the past year, the Fed has been striving to make the dollar buy less. It's well on its way to succeeding, to judge by the recent readings on wholesale and consumer prices.
 Why the Fed decided to propagate inflation, after having so long battled against it, is a story that begins with the return to common usage of an old word. Late in 2002, officials began to warn of the danger of ''deflation,'' or broadly falling prices. Everyday low prices are well and good, the central bankers allowed. Yet if prices steadily and predictably fell, people would stop buying things. They would stay home to wait for tomorrow's guaranteed lower prices. And if the American consumer stopped shopping -- and borrowing to shop -- where would we be? 
 So, last June 25, the Fed pushed the federal funds rate, the rate it directly controls, down to 1 percent, the lowest since the second Eisenhower administration. And it warned that ''the probability, though minor, of an unwelcome substantial fall in inflation exceeds that of a pickup in inflation from its already low level.''
 Before the Fed was founded, in 1913, there were recurrent cycles of inflation and deflation. In general, prices rose in wartime and fell in peacetime. In the last quarter of the 19th century, prices persistently fell. Technological innovation pushed down costs, and lower costs translated into lower prices. Wage-earners flourished as the spending power of money increased. Creditors prospered, too, as interest rates declined.
 Then, about 1900, the world struck gold -- in Alaska, Colorado and South Africa. As gold was then the monetary asset on which national currencies were based, the world, in effect, struck money. For the next two decades, prices went up.
 It is a relatively new thing in finance that prices should not be allowed to fall. The Federal Reserve implicitly admits as much. On the one hand, it extols the rising productivity of the United States economy. On the other, it declares that this extraordinary progress should not be registered in falling prices. In so many words, the central bank says that what is good for Wal-Mart's customers is not necessarily good for the country.
 The Fed doesn't literally print money. Instead, it manipulates the interest rate that induces others to print money. In a modern economy, money-printing takes the form of credit creation, i.e., lending and borrowing.
 There has been a great deal of this in recent years. By any and all measures, America is more heavily indebted than ever before. In 1958, when the funds rate was last at 1 percent, the economy's overall indebtedness was about half of today's. Back then, overall debt (excluding the borrowings of banks and the federal government) represented 84 percent of gross domestic product. Nowadays, it stands at 163 percent of G.D.P.
 The weight of this indebtedness, foreign as well as domestic, helps to explain why the Fed set its rate so low. One percent is an emergency rate, unseen before the institution of the Fed and only rarely since. It was the rate intended to raise the economy from the Great Depression and to see it through World War II and the immediate cold war era.
 The Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, and his colleagues keep saying that there is no emergency -- that, on the contrary, the United States economy is a paragon of strength, lacking only an acceptable rate of job creation. Yet they have kept their rate at the emergency setting, thus fomenting a real-estate boom on Main Street and a stock-and-bond boom on Wall Street.
 Now the 1 percent era is fast closing, and financial markets worldwide are shuddering. As the signs of inflation multiply, the Fed finds itself in a very interesting position. It never wanted much inflation, it protests; just a whiff would suffice.
 But the subjects in the central bank's monetary experiment are human beings, not laboratory mice. When people sense that prices are going to rise, they take steps to protect themselves. They buy extra inventory, invest in so-called hard assets (houses, not bonds) and pass along their rising costs as best they can. Once instilled, inflationary habits are hard to break, as the Fed exactly understands.
 And the Fed will raise its rate, though grudgingly and gradually. It will act in this fashion not only out of conviction but also, perhaps, out of a guilty conscience. It knows that its 1 percent rate drove many risk-averse people into stocks and bonds because they could no longer afford to live on the meager returns of their savings. That is at one pole of the spectrum of financial sophistication. At the other, hedge funds borrowed at ultra-low rates to speculate in everything from gold to lead. Just the prospect of a slightly higher borrowing rate has brought about disturbances in the temples of high finance.
 The Fed has another reason to be conscience-stricken. It knows, or should know, that by trying to make the dollar cheaper, it has precipitated even more borrowing in an economy heavily encumbered. The greater the debt, the more deflation-prone the economy. And the more deflation-prone the economy, the more the Fed is apt to try to cheapen the dollar. The truth is that the central bank of the United States is chasing its tail. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: At $2 a Gallon, Gas Is Still Worth Guzzling

BYLINE: By DANNY HAKIM

DATELINE: YPSILANTI, Mich. 

 BODY:
AN informal poll of drivers filling up on Friday at a Sunoco gas station, where unleaded starts at $2.05, showed the frustrations over rising energy prices.
 ''It's ridiculous,'' said Abby Lochotzki, 22, a student at Eastern Michigan University filling up a Chevy Blazer.
 ''Outrageous,'' said Kashania Thrower, 22, who works at a local rehab clinic. 
 Are people driving any less?
 ''I don't drive as much and I walk places I can walk to,'' Ms. Lochotzki said.
 Marci Gilchrist, 49, a mother of two filling a Ford Taurus wagon, said she sought out the station because the price was a little lower than at her home in nearby Ann Arbor, Mich.
 ''Where I live, it's about $2.15,'' she said.
 Still, Americans are probably not going to rush out and ditch their pickup trucks for compact cars. And in a nation where mass transit is largely unavailable and the road trip beloved, people will have to be pushed hard to change their habits. 
 Gas prices hit a national average of $1.94 per gallon last week, but prices in the early 1970's, adjusted for inflation, hit $3 per gallon at their peak. And that was at a time when consumers were suffering from deeper economic malaise. 
 Today's S.U.V. buyers may feel pinched at $2 per gallon, but that's still way below the $5 per gallon levels that have Europeans driving cars so small they would be Hummer-fodder on American streets. 
 ''Once you start to get over $3.50, $4, closer to European prices, we'll perhaps see driving habits change,'' said Charlie Vogelheim, executive editor at Kelley Blue Book, which tracks new and used car values. ''Maybe people will carpool and won't take as many trips.'' 
 In a study conducted last month by Kelley and the polling firm Harris Interactive, about 40 percent of 1,700 car shoppers said high gas prices would have an effect on their decision. And last month did see a sharp falloff in demand for the largest S.U.V's, with the Ford Expedition, Hummer H2 and Chevrolet Suburban all down at least 20 percent from a year earlier. 
 Still, one month's data is just one month's data, and hiccups are not unheard of. Most analysts think it will take a lot more to knock Americans out of their gas guzzlers. In the 2003 model year, the average light-duty vehicle weighed more than two tons for the first time since the mid 1970's. 
 ''People are beginning the thought process but not really changing their habits,'' said Mr. Vogelheim. ''But it begins with the consciousness starting.''
 So what would it really take? 
 Maybe the $100-fillup, Mr. Vogelheim said, adding that Californians who own the Ford Excursion, which has a 44-gallon tank, already have to shell out five twenties to fill up in their state. 
 Robert Schnorbus, chief economist for J.D. Power & Associates, said, ''Big S.U.V. sales were down uncharacteristically last month, but I'm not sure that signifies much yet.
 ''I think the consumer is getting more concerned that this is going to last a lot longer than these price spikes have in the past,'' he said. ''But even at $2 a gallon, the additional cost spread out over the ownership cycle isn't likely to be enough to make people dramatically change their buying patterns.''
 ''The price of oil,'' Mr. Schnorbus added, ''is still cheaper than bottled water and milk.''

HEADLINE: Producing Gold Teeth, Dentures and Jobs

BYLINE: By Terry Pristin

 BODY:
EDWARD RICCOBONO, a burly man with a gregarious manner, is carrying a black velvet tray of the type that might be used to display high-end jewelry. Instead, he is showing off some of his products: a 24-karat gold tooth that will be covered in porcelain, a metal frame that will hold a partial denture, and a company specialty, a flexible pink gasket known as a Cu-Sil denture, which is gentler than metal on the adjoining teeth.
 ''Everything we do is custom-made,'' said Mr. Riccobono, who started in the business by working for his father. ''There are no cookie-cutter items that we do.'' 
 Mr. Riccobono and his partner, Robert Y. Wallace, run Nu-Life Dental Laboratories, a company with 29 employees that has been making crowns and dentures in Brooklyn since 1958. Located above a Duane Reade store on a bustling stretch of Kings Highway, the offices are not much to look at, with worn workbenches that were part of the original furnishings. But the business itself is hardly as antiquated as its surroundings. In one room, a computer-operated machine transforms wax models into porcelain crowns.
 With so much attention focused on Wall Street and Fortune 500 companies, it is easy to forget that New York is essentially a city of small businesses. Of the more than 200,000 companies in New York, 96.5 percent have 49 employees or fewer, said James P. Brown, an analyst with the State Department of Labor. Small companies also account for most of the new jobs, said Jonathan Bowles, research director for the Center for an Urban Future, a nonpartisan research group.
 Nu-Life, however, nearly became one of those businesses that could no longer make a go of it in New York.
 About 500 dentists and 20 hospitals in the metropolitan area buy from Nu-Life, but they have many other laboratories to choose from, including mom-and-pop operations with much lower overhead, Mr. Riccobono said. So Nu-Life can charge its customers only a fraction of what the dentists bill their patients, he said.
 And, as the neighborhood has prospered, the company's rent has been rising. Over the past decade, it has gone to $9,000 a month from about $2,000, he said. About 18 months ago, Mr. Riccobono decided it was time for Nu-Life to have a building of its own. He wanted to stay in Brooklyn, but at first his only options seemed to be in industrial neighborhoods, where his employees might not feel safe after dark. ''The single biggest problem small manufacturers have,'' Mr. Bowles said, ''is not taxes or energy, but real estate.''
 So Mr. Riccobono began looking on Long Island, where there were more buildings to choose from, and in New Jersey, which offered juicy incentives. ''Some of them would take my whole lifetime to use up,'' he said.
 New York offers incentives, too, but Mr. Riccobono never imagined that a business the size of Nu-Life could partake of them because most of the focus in recent years has been on large corporate recipients. Under Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, the city has not entirely ended what the mayor has described as ''corporate welfare,'' but it has become more selective and less generous when dealing with large companies. 
 When Mr. Riccobono finally found a building in Mill Basin, Brooklyn, on Mill Avenue near Avenue U, the city was able to help him with $488,000 in tax abatements under a program for small manufacturers administered by the Industrial Development Agency, an arm of the City Economic Development Corporation. Successful applicants must ''demonstrate to us that the project wouldn't go forward without our help,'' said Barbara Basser-Bigio, the agency's executive director.
 Nu-Life is paying $1 million for the building and spending $250,000 on improvements. It will have roughly the same amount of space it has now, about 4,000 square feet, but will be able to install modern workstations, with room for 12 additional workers. Mr. Riccobono plans to hire six after the move. 
 Since January 2002, the program for small manufacturers has helped 45 industrial companies, keeping 2,500 jobs in New York and creating 1,500 more, said Valerie J. Rutstein, a vice president of the development corporation. With the economy improving, ''we think this is going to grow in the next couple of years,'' she said. ''Things are picking up substantially.''

HEADLINE: Psst. Why Insider Trading Keeps Going.

BYLINE: By LANDON THOMAS Jr.

 BODY:
ARRIVING in Las Vegas for a board meeting of Interstate Bakeries, E. Garrett Bewkes Jr., a director, called his son, Robert, a broker at UBS, at his home in Darien, Conn. The two men talked almost every day, swapping bits of family and market gossip, and this day, in February 2003, was no exception.
 The conversation occurred hours before the board meeting began. Mr. Bewkes, who had been given an internal report documenting the company's deteriorating financial condition, complained to his son that ''business was lousy,'' according to regulatory filings. Mr. Bewkes, a former Paine Webber director, added that if his son owned any of the stock in Interstate, which makes Wonder bread and Hostess cakes, he should get rid of it. ''I don't see the stock going anywhere for a long time,'' he concluded, according to the filings.
 Ten minutes later, Robert Bewkes, a broker at UBS for 12 years, sold $230,000 worth of Interstate Bakeries stock for himself, his family and a few select clients, filings show. For the Bewkeses, what had begun as a father-and-son chat suddenly became something much more ominous, according to regulators: trading on inside information. 
 A week later, Interstate warned the public of a major earnings shortfall, and its stock sank 25 percent that day. (The bad news came just four months after Samuel D. Waksal pleaded guilty to insider trading in stock of his company, ImClone Systems.) The New York Stock Exchange, on the lookout for unusual trading before stocks rose or fell rapidly, promptly opened an investigation of trading in Interstate. Just as quickly, they turned up Robert Bewkes's timely sale of 16,000 shares, linking him to the director with the same surname.
 The Bewkeses settled civil claims last month with the Securities and Exchange Commission, which had accused them of violating securities laws by making use of nonpublic information for trading purposes. Robert Bewkes, who resigned from his job at UBS last June, accepted a five-year ban from the securities industry and agreed to pay $137,306. The elder Mr. Bewkes (pronounced BEW-kess) paid a $67,517 fine and stepped down from his directorship at Interstate last July. He also resigned from the boards of a number of UBS mutual funds. Neither man admitted any wrongdoing, and neither agreed to be interviewed for this article. UBS and Interstate Bakeries also declined to comment.
 The Bewkes saga was a devastating blow for the family, of course. But it also suggests that despite the intense public scrutiny of recent celebrity insider-trading cases, like those of Mr. Waksal and Martha Stewart, Wall Street insiders -- who in theory should know better than anyone -- still violate securities laws by misusing nonpublic information. The S.E.C. brought 50 insider-trading cases last year, roughly on par with the number pursued in each of the previous five years.
 Federal prosecutors have aggressively gone after wrongdoers. Mr. Waksal, the founder of ImClone Systems, was sentenced to seven years in prison after being found guilty of passing on inside information to his daughter. And while Ms. Stewart, a friend, was not found guilty of insider trading, she was convicted of lying to investigators about her own ImClone stock sales in an attempt to keep the government from filing insider-trading charges against her. 
 THE S.E.C., in fact, has a civil case of insider trading pending against Ms. Stewart and her broker, Peter E. Bacanovic. That case had been shelved while she was tried for criminal obstruction of justice. She now faces the possibility of going to prison for that conviction, and the S.E.C. will pursue the civil insider-trading case once the judge in her criminal case gives them permission to do so.
 Investigators acknowledge that they are not sure why some of the smartest people in and around Wall Street continue to run afoul of insider-trading laws when so much attention is being lavished on the crime. ''We don't know why people do these things sometimes,'' said Mark K. Schoenfeld, a top enforcement official in the S.E.C.'s New York office, where most insider-trading cases are prosecuted. ''One thing we can't account for are lapses in judgment.''
 Whim, tragic error and greed are motivating forces, investigators say. But ultimately, they cite a sense that Wall Street insiders think the information they use to make trades is so privileged -- so ''inside'' -- that no one will know they used it. ''A lot of people engage in white-collar transgressions because they think they won't get caught,'' said Dennis B. Levine, who spent more than a year in prison after he was convicted, in 1986, of trading on inside information. ''One thing I learned is that there are really smart guys working at the S.E.C. and the U.S. attorney's office.'' He says he always tells people, ''Just don't do it.''
 For Mr. Levine, who now runs his own consulting firm and lectures business school students on the perils of violating securities laws, the pain and embarrassment he felt are still fresh in his mind, causing him to wonder why people continue to make the same mistakes. ''One would think that the government's ability to ferret out improper trading activities, as well as the stiffer sentences, would act as a deterrent,'' he said. 
 As anyone who knows Eugene Garret Bewkes will tell you, he is no Dennis Levine or Sam Waksal -- or Martha Stewart, for that matter. A millionaire several times over who splits his time between homes in Vero Beach, Fla., and Nantucket, Mass., Mr. Bewkes, who is 76, has a discreet, understated manner that harks back to the 60's and 70's, when chief executives were not pop icons, flaunting their wealth and flashy lifestyles. He made a name for himself in the 1980's by turning around poorly performing companies. His peers describe him as the most ethical man they know. 
 ''He is a man of absolute integrity and character,'' said Donald B. Marron, the former chairman and chief executive of Paine Webber and a longtime friend of Mr. Bewkes. ''He has a good business record, too. He is a good guy, and that's important in relationships.''
 His two other sons are also well-regarded executives: Jeffrey L. Bewkes is chairman of the entertainment and networks division of Time Warner and a leading candidate to eventually succeed Richard D. Parsons as chief executive of the company; E. Garrett Bewkes III is a veteran Wall Street deal maker who was once co-head of Bear Stearns's investment banking division.
 Still, given their father's high standards and the 40 years he has spent as a senior executive and a director on a wide range of corporate boards, it is surprising that he spoke so cavalierly about selling Interstate Bakeries stock when he had information that would eventually set the stock reeling. More surprising is that his son acted on it. Friends say that the two speak as often as four times a day, and that the call by the senior Mr. Bewkes was not a deliberate attempt to sell stock in advance of pending bad news. Instead, they say, it was just jocular banter between father and son that went horribly wrong when the son, taking for granted that his father would never break the law, put in the sell orders. Nor did the father try to deceive regulators, as Ms. Stewart did; on the contrary, people involved in the investigation said, he swiftly pursued a settlement with the S.E.C. when confronted with the evidence.
 Greed did not seem to be a motive. Robert Bewkes ultimately saved $67,517 in losses for himself and his clients, a relatively modest amount for a veteran stockbroker who owns a rambling house on the outskirts of the exclusive Wee Burn Country Club in Darien. None of the stock he sold belonged to his father. In their complaint, regulators allege that Mr. Bewkes aimed to help his son both personally and professionally by tipping him off. In so doing, they contend, he violated perhaps the most bedrock concept of securities law: that a company director has a fiduciary obligation to keep nonpublic news from being used for stock market gains. ''People in these positions should know better,'' Mr. Schoenfeld said. ''It's a small amount and thus less graphic and venal, but it was still done with an intent to confer a benefit on the son.''
 If professional advancement, or just professional pride, was the motivating factor for the Bewkeses, it would not be unusual. John M. Youngdahl, a former economist from Goldman Sachs and the son of a highly regarded Wall Street executive, pleaded guilty last year to wire fraud and securities fraud for having prematurely disclosed to Goldman's bond traders that the Treasury Department would be halting its 30-year bond sales. While Goldman made $4.3 million by trading on the information -- and would later pay $9 million to settle with regulators -- Mr. Youngdahl saw no financial gain whatsoever. Later this month he will leave his two children, his wife and his house in the affluent suburb of Summit, N.J., and start a 33-month prison term.
 Mr. Youngdahl also declined to be interviewed. But with his career gone, his name sullied and the prospect of years in prison away from his family, Mr. Youngdahl described to his lawyer his feelings of ignominy. 
 Steven Cohen, one of Mr. Youngdahl's lawyers, said: ''I told him it's like 'The Trial' in Kafka. But he said: 'No, it's not ''The Trial.'' It's ''Metamorphosis.'' I woke up one morning and suddenly I'm a cockroach.'''
 The Bewkes case illustrates the length of such a fall. The elder Mr. Bewkes, after graduation from the Deerfield Academy in Massachusetts and Yale Law School, began his career as a tax lawyer and became an executive at Norton Simon, a conglomerate that owned Canada Dry and other companies, in the 1970's. In 1982, he became chief executive of American Bakeries, which he eventually bought with a group of investors; in 1988, parts of it were sold to Interstate Bakeries. In 1991, he became a director of Interstate, and was on the board of Paine Webber from 1987 to 2000, when the firm was acquired by UBS.
 It was, in fact, his use of a UBS corporate cellphone to call his son that led regulators -- who were already looking at Interstate trading and the relationship between the Bewkeses -- to conclude that there might have been an exchange of inside information between father and son. 
 Friends and relatives of the Bewkeses said they were not surprised, in retrospect, that the elder Mr. Bewkes -- consciously or not -- tried to help his son that day. They said that Robert, who is 48, did not have the competitive business genes of his brothers and that he relied on an occasional helping hand from his father. ''Bob is a wonderful guy, but he was always looked out for more,'' said Lawrence Jerome, his first cousin and the best man at his wedding. ''He never had the drive that his brothers had. I think it was just a case of a good father trying to direct his son to use the skills that he has.''
 ALTHOUGH Robert started out at the Deerfield Academy, then a boys' prep school, where his father was a trustee and where his two elder brothers had thrived, he never embraced the school's high-octane competitive spirit and left after two years because of illness, finishing high school elsewhere. His brother Jeff went to Yale, and his brother Garrett went to St. Lawrence, where their grandfather once was president. Robert went to Syracuse University.
 Robert Bewkes's first job after graduation was as a sales manager at Canada Dry, where his father had worked, and in 1991 he became a broker at Paine Webber, where his father was a director. He stayed there after UBS bought the firm and remained until last year. A gregarious sort, he took to the social aspect of a broker's job, but never became a significant producer there, looking out primarily for accounts of family and friends, according to people who have seen his employment records at UBS.
 Now banned from the financial industry for five years, he is working in partnership with a friend, renovating houses. He has children in private school and a large house in Darien to maintain, and some family members worry about his future.
 ''I don't think Bob is worth a great pot of money,'' said Mr. Jerome, his cousin. ''I know he feels terrible about this. He let his father down. I don't know how you come to terms with that. If he hadn't picked up the phone, none of this would have happened.''

HEADLINE: Black, White and Brown

BYLINE: By Sam Tanenhaus

 BODY:
On the occasion of the 50th anniversary of the Supreme Court's Brown v. Board of Education decision, Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of the Book Review, moderated a discussion of the historic ruling between Cornel West, whose new book, ''Democracy Matters,'' will be published in September, and Henry Louis Gates Jr., whose latest book is ''African American Lives,'' edited with Evelyn Brooks Higginbotham. A fuller, video version of the conversation is available at nytimes.com/books.

Unintended Consequences Of the Brown Decision
 Gates. I was born in 1950. Brown v. Board's in 1954. Schools in Mineral County, W.Va., which is about three hours west of D.C., integrated in 1955. I started school in 1956. So my entire life, because of Brown v. Board, I went to integrated schools. My town had 2,100 people in 1950, 386 of whom were black. So you can see just from the stats why integration occurred so quickly. It was inefficient to have two separate school systems. [So] they fired all the black teachers except one from the elementary school and one, the principal, from the high school and integrated them into the white staff at the white schools.
 For me the most problematic aspect of Brown was the fundamental premise that separate inherently spelled unequal. Curiously enough, I find myself agreeing with Clarence Thomas when he argues that there was a perverse aspect to the logic of Brown v. Board.
 West. But I think it's really important to keep in mind what the vital options at a particular historical moment are. Given America's vicious legacy of white supremacy, [the Brown legal team] had to argue against separate but equal because that's already inscribed in Plessy v. Ferguson.
 Gates. You're absolutely correct. In their time they had no choice. But they also happened to have believed that all-black institutions were inherently inferior and that many of them would disappear very quickly, and all the better for it. In 1937 Richard Wright wrote that once the goals of a nation's civil rights movement are realized, Negro literature as an institution would disappear. We would produce a new kind of integrated society. And we see that legacy in many of the reform movements that abound today trying to address the problem of resegregation.
 West. There's a certain complication here. When Charles Hamilton Houston takes over the deanship in 1929 at Howard, he tries to Harvard-ize it. He realized Howard could not even begin to compete with Harvard. But he also knew that after a decade or two Howard would be better than many white law schools, though maybe not Harvard. Now in that sense he doesn't believe that the black folk by themselves are inferior vis-a-vis white institutions, only the elite white institutions. They're going to outcompete a lot of the white law schools. Why? Because he's bringing in some top-notch black professors, and white professors too.

Brown 1 Versus Brown 2
 West. We have to keep in mind what the dominant response was in 1954. It was white resistance. It was white backlash. We don't have any substantive remedies. So there was a ''Brown 2'' in 1955 having to do with the remedy, ''all deliberate speed.'' [The decision was to leave it to] the federal district judges, [who] over and over again affirmed local control. And local control meant you're going to follow the de facto segregation patterns in residence, in property taxes and so on.
 Gates. What we're talking about really is how to deal with the conflict between quality and community. Many of our friends on the left would have us believe that all black people want their kids bused out of the inner cities. [But] what they want from busing is quality. If we could make predominantly black schools excellent, would that be a satisfactory goal? I say yes, because I don't think there's anything magic about being around white people. I think it's good for a multicultural society to have integration. But unless we have economic integration, we're not going to have residential integration. And unless the schools have quality, we're not going to have economic integration. We [also] need a revolution within the African-American community insisting on a change in attitude, behavior and morals. Deferred gratification, staying in school, doing your homework, reminding people in a programmatic way that the blackest thing you could be historically was an educated man or an educated woman within the African-American community.

From Brown to Affirmative Action
 Gates. At Yale, the class of 1966 had six black boys. The class of 1973, which I entered in September 1969, had 96 black men and women. What was there, a genetic blip in the race and all of a sudden there are 90 smart black people who exist in 1969 who hadn't existed in 1966? Of course not. [Before affirmative action] you couldn't just show up in the black community and apply [to Yale]. You had to go through filters within the race. You had to know somebody. There were these mechanisms. It's the same [with] Rosa Parks. She did not spontaneously sit down on that bus. She was chosen for the role. She was trained. The way the mythology is perpetuated, she was tired, she was poor, she was black, and she sat down. Well, no, that's not how it happened.
 West. This is why the conservative appropriation of Brown 1 is phony. We all agree with the affirmation of the principle of equality. Now Brown 2 says the remedies for this injustice are going to be left up to local custom, local courts. The 1960's came along and we had to come up with more aggressive strategies [to integrate] institutions of higher learning. Unfortunately, as we know -- and this is where I think some of the conservatives are right -- so much more time needs to be spent with K through 12, but it's precisely because of the conservative support of policies that made it difficult for grade schools to be adequately supported that affirmative action became a kind of third wave to deal with injustice.

Is There Segregation Today in the Ivy League?
 West. There are certain social patterns of what I call soft segregation. Many of the faculty of all colors at Princeton encourage the students to be multicontextual. There's nothing wrong with black students spending time with black students, Catholic students spending time with Catholic students and so forth. But you don't want to get locked into that one context.
 Gates. It's the difference between enforced segregation and willing association. I give all these speeches for the Harvard Alumni Association. Invariably, there is a question -- it's always a white person, and they put it in a euphemistic way: Do all the students still sit together in the cafeteria? Yes, it's so sad. Every time I walk into the dining hall, I shake my head -- all those white students sitting together. I say, man, look at all these white kids and a handful of black people. Harvard is not like Harlem.
 I don't know if we went through a period of great desegregation and I missed it. I mean it was great for me, it was great for you. I don't have the historical statistics, but I certainly have the statistics at hand for the situation today. In the Boston metro area, 7 in 10 white students attend schools in the outer suburbs, schools that are over 90 percent white. By contrast, more than three-quarters of black and Latino students attend schools in the city or in one of the urbanized satellite cities. Segregated minority schools in metro Boston are also high-poverty schools. The black middle class has moved out, moved into the suburbs. What it means is that these all-black-and-brown schools not only are all-black-and-brown but they are poor. 
 West. One has to say this almost in a comic mode, but if it becomes a matter of national security, then there will be equality of opportunity across the board. That is to say, you're telling folk, your whole democratic experiment is going to go under if you don't provide at least more economic opportunity. It's almost like Iraq, the war against terror; this is national security. When it comes to the plight of poor children, especially poor black and brown children, it's difficult for many citizens to conceive of them as being integral to the public interest.
 Gates. The identification of interests, the sharing of common interests between the black middle, upper middle classes and the black people stuck behind, is [more] important than shared class identification between white members of the upper middle class and black members of the upper middle class. Why? Because if the black middle class abandons the black underclass, there will be no hope. People are not willingly going to redistribute wealth. It's just against human nature. You have to persuade them that it's a good idea.
 West. What you're saying, though, is that it's not in the name of one citizen's status that one tries to enhance the situation of the most vulnerable, but [only] in the name of some communal ethnic racial identity. Why? It's up to the black middle class to save the black poor because the other citizens in the larger democratic republic don't have a major interest in that. Now if that's the case, it's a very sad commentary.

SECTION: Section 2; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk; Pg. 25; TELEVISION: THE EPISODE

LENGTH: 1212 words

HEADLINE: The Forensic Evidence Is In, And It Points to New York

BYLINE: By ROBERT LEVINE

 BODY:
MINUTES into tomorrow's episode of ''C.S.I.: Miami,'' at 10 p.m. on CBS, a teenage girl returns home from a night of clubbing and finds the dead bodies of her parents. It's a standard opening for cop shows, especially the kind of series known as police procedurals, which focus on detective work, but only on the ''C.S.I.'' programs would the girl find out about her mother by tapping her from behind to wake her up -- then watching her head fall off her neck.
 On ''C.S.I.: Miami,'' dead bodies tell tales, and tomorrow's headless mother must somehow point the way to New York, which will provide the setting for a spin-off series, ''C.S.I.: New York.'' Two years ago, the original ''C.S.I.'' introduced ''C.S.I.: Miami'' in a plot that brought its Las Vegas-based squad to Florida. This time around, the producers chose ''Miami'' to introduce ''New York'' because, as one of the characters says in the course of the episode, Miami is ''the sixth borough.'' Not incidentally, this third installment is set in the same city as that other crime mini-empire, ''Law and Order'' and its soon-to-be-three siblings. Like ''Law and Order,'' the ''C.S.I.'' series share a basic narrative formula -- in this case, grisly crimes solved by the end of the hour on the basis of forensic evidence. 
 So in addition to telling a self-contained, satisfyingly complex mystery story, the show's writers had to construct a plausible reason for Horatio Caine, the lead investigator on ''C.S.I.: Miami,'' played by David Caruso, to travel to Manhattan. There, the episode must introduce and define the lead ''C.S.I.: New York'' characters well enough to give viewers a sense of what to expect in the fall -- all in 44 minutes. ''You're making a whole new world,'' said Ann Donahue, the show runner for ''C.S.I.: Miami'' and a co-creator, with Carol Mendelsohn and Anthony E. Zuiker, of ''C.S.I.: New York.'' ''You have to show New York the way you want the world to see it. And then you have to introduce five new characters. That's a ton to do.''
 Caine ends up traveling north because of the promise he makes to Laura Spelman, the teenager who found her parents' bodies, to catch her parents' killers. Forensic evidence at the scene -- phlegm that reveals a respiratory inflammation common to New Yorkers who live near ground zero, threads unique to the seat pattern of a small airline -- points to a suspect in Manhattan. Local cops could probably handle it, but, as Caine says with typical tough-guy attitude, ''New York homicide didn't make a promise to Laura Spelman.''
 When Caine arrives at the suspect's New York address, he finds a crime scene -- and the crime scene investigator who will be the lead character of the new series, Detective Mack (Mac) Taylor, played by Gary Sinise. A quick, staccato exchange between Caine and Taylor (They. Talk. Like. This.) about who gets to prosecute the perp defines them as focused and competent with the economical characterization typical of the show. ''All three of the 'C.S.I.' stars are driven in their own different way,'' said Ms. Donahue, referring to the characters played by William Petersen on the original show, Mr. Caruso and now Mr. Sinise. On ''C.S.I.,'' as on ''Law and Order,'' characters are defined purely in terms of work, and they don't seem to get out of the office much anyway. ''C.S.I.: New York'' will be more character-driven, in part to differentiate it from the other two shows, but only slightly, said Mr. Zuiker, the show runner for the new series and the creator of the original. ''When you bring people home to see Dad, it's not our show.''
 Like Taylor, the other New York characters are variations on a ''C.S.I.'' theme of public servants so dedicated to justice they're willing to get elbow-deep in innards for it. Later in the episode, more of the murderer's victims are found in a Fifth Avenue apartment building, and another major New York character, Stella Bonasera (Melina Kanakaredes), is introduced as she's running after a guy on a gurney, hounding medics to let her take pictures of his injury for evidence. ''The kid's been shot and she doesn't care -- she wants a picture of the wound because the wound can tell her about the case,'' Ms. Donahue said. The dialogue is particular to the setting -- ''there really is a New York attitude,'' Ms. Donahue said -- but the dedication is common to the ''C.S.I.'' characters. All of them have the kind of single-minded focus one would value in a colleague but might dread in someone at a cocktail party.
 In New York, of course, some of the criminals will be just as single-minded -- in part because of the harsher conditions in the city. ''When you have to bundle up and fight to get into Manhattan to get to your job, that makes you different than the girl that's in Miami, which is peaceful and placid,'' Ms. Donahue said. ''That's the kind of girl you'll be able to break really quickly.'' 
 As in many episodes of all the shows, solving the crime requires navigating a particular subculture, and tomorrow night Taylor and Caine follow the evidence left by a low-life to a high-rise on Fifth Avenue. An important part of the trail consists of the metallic particles found in the upper respiratory tracts of some downtown New Yorkers, and what ultimately unlocks the secrets of that world is, literally, a key. Each episode of every ''C.S.I.'' contains elements of science unknown to the average viewer -- ''what's going to excite us is something we didn't previously know,'' Ms. Donahue said -- and both are examples of how the shows deal with real-world scientific principles.
 In the case of the keys, the writers wanted something that was specific to New York, not only in terms of evidence, like the respiratory inflammation, but in terms of tone. Since the show often plays up the forensic possibilities of everyday items, keys fit the bill. ''There are so few things that are so New York and one of them is keys,'' Ms. Donahue said, since so many people leave them with neighbors they actually don't know that well. One of the principles of forensics is that objects leave traces of themselves against other objects, as a key might in a lock. ''There's a whole world of locks!'' Ms. Donahue said. And that science, along with, as is usual for ''C.S.I.,'' some bodily fluids best left unmentioned here, help the investigators close in on a motive for the killer.
 By the end of the episode, the truth comes out, in the form of iron-clad evidence that lacks the subjective squishiness of courtroom testimony. That ability to establish truth beyond doubt is how Ms. Donahue said the ''C.S.I.'' writers make their Q-Tip-wielding protagonists seem as heroic as their action-hero counterparts. ''I really believe that what the C.S.I.'s have, thanks to science, is superpowers,'' Ms. Donahue said.
 The show's basis in science won't change, although how that works in the story might play out differently in New York. ''The Sinise character knows that the secret about New York is that people love to talk,'' Ms. Donahue said. ''They want to unburden their secrets, but sometimes they need a reason. And for him, the evidence is that reason. He gets to lay down the evidence and say, 'Look, I know this is hard for you to say, but let me start the story for you.' ''

HEADLINE: As Mortgage Rates Rise, Dreams Are Downsized

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
HOME shoppers have been losing purchasing power week by week because of the surge in mortgage interest rates. Eventually, that should take some of the zip out of the economy.
 Last week, the national average rate on a 30-year mortgage jumped to 6.34 percent, according to Freddie Mac. That is up almost a percentage point from March 18, when the rate was 5.38 percent. Last June, the average was only 5.21 percent, the lowest since Freddie Mac began recording rates in 1971. 
 The increases have already had a big impact on the prices that people can pay for houses. At 5.38 percent, a monthly payment of $1,120.57 would handle a 30-year mortgage of $200,000. At the current rate of 6.34 percent, that same monthly payment would cover a mortgage of only $180,276 -- almost 10 percent less.
 Mortgage rates will move higher, and purchasing power will fall further, if interest rates rise as forecast. Blue Chip Economic Indicators is predicting that the yield on the Treasury's 10-year note will average 5.2 percent in the second quarter of next year. Add 1.5 percentage points to that, which is the way the Mortgage Bankers Association forecasts future mortgage rates, and that equals a mortgage rate of 6.7 percent in next year's second quarter. 
 That would translate into a cut in purchasing power of 13.2 percent since March of this year and 14.8 percent since June 2003.
 Because of the expected climb in rates, the association predicts that sales of existing and new homes, as well as housing starts, will fall modestly by the second quarter of 2005.
 For now, though, the consensus on Wall Street is that rising interest rates have not yet led to a significant slowdown in the construction of new housing. Economists expect only a 1.3 percent decline in April housing starts, which the government reports this week, to an annual rate of 1.980 million, from 2.007 million in March, according to Bloomberg's consensus forecast. That would be just a little below the 1.987 million average for the last six months. 
 LESS TO SPEND Rising mortgage rates have already caused a plunge in the number of mortgage refinancings, which have given Americans billions of extra dollars to spend.
 In 2003, the additional cash from refinancings totaled about $200 billion. In each refinancing in which homeowners took out some cash, the extra pocket money averaged $20,000 to $30,000, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. Since the week ended March 19, new refinancing applications have plunged 56 percent, and they are down 78 percent from their record high at the end of last May.
 EXIT LEFT Another casualty of the climb in interest rates has been the high-yield bond market. So far this year, it is showing an overall loss of 1.7 percent, according to Merrill Lynch bond indexes. Since the yield on the Treasury's 10-year note began rising from its 2004 low in March, the high-yield loss has been 3.5 percent. Last year, the total return for high-yield bonds was 28.1 percent, the best ever. 
 Investors have taken notice. In the week ended on Wednesday, they pulled $2.2 billion out of high-yield mutual funds, according to AMG Data Services. That is the second-biggest net weekly outflow in AMG's data history, which goes back to 1992. Compared with the same periods of earlier years, this year's net outflow through Wednesday is the largest ever.

LENGTH: 1299 words

HEADLINE: Moving On, Down I-95

BYLINE: By J.D. REED

DATELINE: PRINCETON 

 BODY:
AS the academic year winds down, farewells float on the soft spring air, U-Haul trailers rest outside dormitories and students hug goodbye.
 In Nassau Hall, Princeton's 18th-century administration building, Amy Gutmann, the provost, was also preparing to move on after 28 years on the faculty. 
 ''I'm taking these two pictures with me, because of their symbolism,'' said Dr. Gutmann, a slight, vigorous woman with a beaming smile. She pointed to a pair of animal prints on the wall of her office. ''The snow owls in that Audubon print represent wisdom, and the aardvark over there represents a thick skin,'' she said with rueful delight. ''I'm going to need both.'' 
 Indeed she will. On July 1, Dr. Gutmann, a renowned political scientist, philosopher and author, will travel an hour south on Interstate 95 to Philadelphia, where she will become the new president of the University of Pennsylvania. 
 Never mind that I-95 is still a bit of a jumble in this part of the state; it will be a challenging trip in another respect. In the rarefied world of Ivy League presidents, Dr. Gutmann, 54, will be taking over from Penn's dynamic leader for the past decade, Judith Rodin, who transformed the school on the Schuylkill into a university with sizzle. 
 Some in academic circles are scratching their heads at the choice of Dr. Gutmann, who at Princeton was dean of the faculty and provost since 2001, second in command to the president, Shirley Tilghman. They question whether her tenure in the bucolic leafiness of Princeton, with its 5,000 undergraduates and exclusive eating clubs, has sufficiently prepared her to lead Penn, a $4 billion organization and Philadelphia's largest private employer, with 25,000 students and a dozen professional schools. 
 Nor was there a shortage of choices. Although James S. Riepe, board chairman at Penn and vice chairman of the investment firm T. Rowe Price, swore the presidential search committee to secrecy, candidates rumored to be on the short list included former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, a Princeton alumnus and Rhodes scholar, and Condoleezza Rice, President Bush's national security adviser, who had been provost of Stanford University. 
 But Mr. Riepe, who was chairman of the search committee, said he had no doubts about Dr. Gutmann. ''When someone says, 'How are you going to get someone to fill Judy Rodin's shoes?''' said Mr. Riepe, ''I say, 'We don't need to fill her shoes. We need someone to lead us through the challenges of the next decade.' And Amy is the one to do it.''
 Dr. Gutmann also likes the fit. ''Right now it is the hot Ivy; they opted for energy over wisdom,'' she said with a laugh. ''No one has accused me of not having energy.'' 
 Even her birthplace seemed right. ''After I had been unanimously elected by the board of trustees, but before it had been publicly announced, we were finally relaxing,'' she recalled. ''One of the trustees leaned over and asked, 'By the way, where were you born?' I told him, 'Brooklyn.' He said, 'We're all from Brooklyn.'''
 Dr. Gutmann's path from the streets of Brooklyn to Eisenlohr Hall, the official residence of Penn presidents, has been an unusual journey. Her father, Kurt Gutmann, fled Germany with his family in 1934 and settled in Bombay, where he founded a metal fabricating factory. On a trip to New York in 1948, he met his future wife, Beatrice.
 ''But he didn't like the big city at all,'' Dr. Gutmann said. ''He was suspicious of it. So we soon moved to Monroe, New York.'' An hour's drive northwest of Brooklyn, Monroe was a tiny town of 4,000 at the time. ''The Woodbury Common, where everyone goes for discount shopping, is across the street from Monroe-Woodbury Central High School, where I attended,'' she explained. 
 After high school, Dr. Gutmann entered the Ivy League by a fluke. ''My father had died the year before I graduated,'' she recalled. ''I applied to Stony Brook and other in-state schools because they were all my mother was able to afford. But she was bragging about me, as mothers will, to our doctor, who told her that Ivy League schools give scholarships.''
 An application later, Ms. Gutmann was accepted at Radcliffe College, where the young math whiz began as a sophomore. 
 ''I was attracted to the social sciences," she recalled. ''But being good with numbers has been a great help in administration.'' 
 She went on to earn a master's degree from the London School of Economics, and returned to Harvard for her doctorate. There she met Michael Doyle, a political scientist who today is the Harold Brown professor of law and international affairs at Columbia University. They wed in 1976, and have a daughter, Abigail, a doctoral student in chemistry at Harvard. 
 For Mr. Doyle, a seasoned Princeton-New York commuter, the move to Philadelphia will mean a change of train lines. ''He now takes New Jersey Transit,'' said Dr. Gutmann. ''After we move he will switch to Amtrak.''
 The move means a great deal more for Dr. Gutmann. 
 ''Dr. Rodin has set the bar very high,'' said Dr. Arthur Rubenstein, dean of the medical school and a search committee member. ''So it's a big challenge for Amy. It's easier to go from middle to high, but hard to go from high to higher.''
 In some aspects, Dr. Gutmann was a natural. A high priority was to find a well-known scholar who could attract the best of faculty to Penn while retaining its current roster. ''She has impeccable academics,'' said Dr. Rubenstein. 
 Indeed, the polymath and peripatetic Dr. Gutmann has held the Laurance S. Rockefeller professorship of politics at Princeton; taught political thought, philosophy and ethics; and founded the University Center for Human Values, a multidisciplinary center that supports scholarship and public lectures. She has also been a fellow at the Institute For Advanced Study.
 But the world of a university president extends far beyond the classroom. Like other college leaders, much of Dr. Gutmann's time and considerable energy will be spent raising funds. She hastens to point out that she has earned her stripes there, too, eliciting $100 million for Princeton's Center for Human Values.
 And while Princeton has an endowment of $8.3 billion, just behind Harvard and Yale, Penn weighs in at $3.5 billion, ninth in the nation -- behind the University of Texas. 
 The number is even more deceiving. ''Because of its small size,'' Mr. Riepe said. ''Princeton can pay for 90 percent of its scholarships from the income on its endowment. Penn can fund only 14 percent. The balance has to come out of operating funds. In that regard we are about 60th.'' 
 In addition, Penn is a vast enterprise, one of the largest landowners in Philadelphia. Its health care system alone includes the nation's second-ranked medical school and two renowned teaching hospitals. There are also top-ranked schools of law, business, nursing, education and design. 
 She has received advice from college presidents past and present, including Dr. Tilghman and Dr. Rodin. ''They all apologize and say, 'I'm going to give you some free advice,''' she said. ''I say, 'Don't apologize! I need it all!'''
 Dr. Gutmann said she and Mr. Doyle are looking forward to moving. ''We're ready for the urban dynamic,'' she said. 
 Still, she will miss her friends of 28 years. Just days earlier, a group including Dr. Tilghman; Harold Shapiro, a former president of Princeton; and Peter Singer, the ethicist and philosopher, gave the couple a farewell brunch. Lionel Grossman, a former chairman of romance languages, composed a poem, which said:
 Let's all raise our glass,
 To a leader of class
 Penn's future great president
 Our hearts' permanent resident.
 Is there anything she won't miss?
 ''The deer,'' said Dr. Gutmann. ''They've ruined my front yard. I'm glad they're not coming to Philadelphia.''

HEADLINE: Another Part of Hoboken Is Luring Developers

BYLINE: By ANTOINETTE MARTIN

DATELINE: HOBOKEN 

 BODY:
AS this port city continues to transform its image from dockside rowdiness to urban chic, less and less likely areas keep emerging as development hot spots.
 Waterfront property is virtually all covered or spoken for -- gone to apartment and condominium complexes with their own parks and retail strips, all claiming skyline views of Manhattan; to office buildings just a short stroll from the diverse restaurants and shops on Washington Street; and to a planned W Hotel at the edge of the Hudson River.
 In addition, the developers Toll Brothers and Pinnacle Downtown plan to tear down the former Maxwell House coffee plant on the waterfront and build 962 apartments with a full-service spa, concierge service, parking and more than 200,000 square feet of office and retail space.
 MOST recently, developers have been focusing on the dilapidated former manufacturing area at the northwest end of town, gutting and rehabbing the big brick carcasses of industry and competing to buy empty lots for construction. The area west of Willow Avenue back to the Palisades Cliffs, occupied by old warehouses and a few rooming houses that survived an era when frequent fires caused the loss of a number of wooden buildings on these streets, is quickly becoming thick with condos, health clubs and bistros catering to a new breed of Hoboken resident. 
 Hoboken is still considered a relative bargain by Manhattanites, brokers say, and continues to attract large numbers of younger people who commute to jobs in Manhattan and partake of the lively night life here. Nearly 70 percent of residents are renters, many of them ensconced in historic brownstones and converted factories.
 Just now, the still somewhat seedy area along Park Avenue near where it intersects a viaduct that becomes 14th Street is heating up as a center of redevelopment. This part of town more or less serves as the gateway to Hoboken for drivers coming off Interstate 495 before it enters the Lincoln Tunnel. 
 ''The area is definitely not prettified yet,'' said Jerry Rockoff of Robert K. Futterman & Associates, a New York-based real estate agency that is working with developers to lease potential retail space at Park Avenue and 14th Street. On the other hand, Mr. Rockoff noted, the property is ''highly visible and located at a heavily traveled intersection, next to what is becoming a prime residential market.''
 The location also offers retail property a rare amenity in this car-choked community: off-street parking.
 The Teaneck-based developer Lawrence J. Bijou, who owns two vacant factory buildings along with the 500-space, five-story Park on Park parking structure on Park Avenue, calls parking the chief obstacle for Hoboken merchants concentrated along Washington Street. ''I can provide ample spots for cars in the garage and on the surface lot behind our buildings at Park and 14th,'' he said. ''This is kind of unheard of.''
 The two former factory buildings owned by his company, Bijou Properties, are in what was a food-processing district. The first, called the Hostess Building, once housed the Continental Baking Company, which produced Twinkies and cupcakes. It occupies a block of 14th Street between Park and Garden Street, and was bought by Bijou two years ago.
 Last month, Bijou bought the Coconut Building on 14th Street, just across Garden Street from the Hostess Building.
 Neither Mr. Bijou nor Mr. Rockoff has been able to discover why it is called that. However, the faded words ''Coconut Desiccation'' appear above the loading dock and several Hoboken history buffs who frequent the diner across the street said they assumed that coconuts arriving at the docks were processed and dried for packaging there.
 The former Lipton Tea Building, which holds a prominent spot between the Hostess building and the Shipyard apartment complex on the waterfront, was converted three years ago into 527 high-end condominiums and renamed the Hudson Tea Building. Two or three residential towers with 800 more units plus a parking deck are scheduled to go up on adjacent vacant land owned by Credit Suisse First Boston, the investment bank. 
 Mr. Bijou plans to add yet more residents to the neighborhood by putting 28 large apartment lofts on the top four floors of the Coconut. The ground floor will provide 10,000 square feet for retail tenants chosen to serve the needs of the nearby residents, he said.
 At the 100-year-old Hostess plant at 210 14th Street, Mr. Rockoff has leased most of the space before renovations have even begun. New York Sports Club will take the whole 23,500-square-foot second story for its second Hoboken center. An Eckerd drugstore will occupy 14,236 square feet at street level, Mr. Rockoff said, leaving only 4,464 feet available.
 ''This new location will complement New York Sports Club's other site on the opposite side of the city, allowing the health club to serve the entire Hoboken community,'' Mr. Rockoff said.
 Eckerd, a subsidiary of the J. C. Penney Company, which has been expanding into new communities in New Jersey, will open its doors in October, as will the sports club, also part of a growing national chain. Eckerd signed a 15-year lease and the sports club a 20-year lease.
 MR. BIJOU said he was focusing his investment on two blocks because he liked to be ''the driving force to some change in one area.''
 ''Bringing industrial property back to life is a good thing, a positive thing, for a community,'' he said. ''And these buildings are handsome, great brick facades, large windows.''
 The area has nonpareil mass transit connections, Mr. Bijou said. The Lincoln Tunnel to Manhattan is a two-minute drive away, with shuttle service available; there is ferry service down the street at the Shipyard; and light rail and PATH train service is within blocks.
 According to the 2000 census, 43.9 percent of Hoboken residents travel to work on public transit.
 Updated census figures indicate that Hoboken now has about 81,000 residents and that most of the housing stock -- 58 percent -- is more than 50 years old. Meanwhile, its population is relatively young, with 48 percent concentrated in the 21 to 44 age group, and a median age of 31.


CORRECTION-DATE: June 6, 2004

 CORRECTION:
An article on May 16 about commercial development in Hoboken, N.J., misstated the city's population. It is 39,507, according to current state estimates. The figure of 81,000 was an estimate of population within a mile of a development site in the northwest section of the city.

HEADLINE: Do You Love Me?

BYLINE: By Joyce Carol Oates. 
Joyce Carol Oates's most recent novel is ''Rape: A Love Story.''

 BODY:

TRUTH & BEAUTY
A Friendship.
By Ann Patchett.
257 pp. New York:
HarperCollins Publishers. $23.95.
 OURS is a memoir-obsessed literary culture. With the waning of confessional poetry, what we might call the ''memoir of crisis'' has blossomed. The strongest of these may be beautifully composed, but beauty is hardly the point. As Robert Lowell famously remarked, ''Yet why not say what happened?''
 Lucy Grealy's ''Autobiography of a Face,'' published in 1994 when she was 31, has become a classic of this genre. Here indeed is a beautifully composed work of literature, a sequence of interlocking essays that explore the author's experiences as a survivor of a disfiguring facial cancer, making pathology a mirror of the human condition. ''Autobiography of a Face'' is also a moving meditation on ugliness and beauty, of particular significance in a culture obsessed with the outward self.
 Stricken with Ewing's sarcoma at the age of 9, Grealy endured years of radiation and chemotherapy followed by a series of reconstructive operations, most of them unsuccessful. Yet it was the anguish of being perceived as ugly, and of feeling ugly, that she identified as the tragedy of her life: ''I was my face, I was ugliness.'' Viciously teased and tormented at school and even as an adult gawked at and occasionally insulted on the street, Grealy came to feel that her suffering as a cancer patient had been minor in comparison.
 In all, Grealy would endure 38 operations until, exhausted and demoralized and increasingly dependent on drugs, she died of an apparent heroin overdose in December 2002 at the age of 39. She had attempted suicide several times and had more or less abandoned her once-promising literary career. As Ann Patchett observes in her memoir of their 17-year friendship, Lucy ''had a nearly romantic relationship with Death. She had beaten it out so many times that she was convinced she could go and kiss it all she wanted and still come out on the other side. . . . She believed that the most basic rules of life did not apply to her.''
 ''Truth & Beauty'' is a harrowing document, composed in a spare, forthright style very different from the elegant artifice of Patchett's best-known novels, ''The Magician's Assistant'' and ''Bel Canto.'' It begins in 1985, when Patchett and Grealy, both recent graduates of Sarah Lawrence, enroll in the University of Iowa Writers' Workshop and room together in an effort to economize. At Sarah Lawrence, Grealy had been famous, not just for the heroic drama of her face but because she was the smartest student in all her classes; by her own modest account, Patchett was less well known.
 From the start, Patchett perceives herself and Grealy as radically different types: ''We were a pairing out of an Aesop's fable, the grasshopper and the ant, the tortoise and the hare. And sure, maybe the ant was warmer in the winter and the tortoise won the race, but everyone knows that the grasshopper and the hare were infinitely more appealing.''
 Patchett is the diligent ant, Grealy the insouciant grasshopper. At their initial meeting in Iowa, though they scarcely know each other, Grealy runs to pitch herself into Patchett's embrace: ''When I turned around to say hello, she shot through the door with a howl. In a second she was in my arms, leaping up onto me, her arms locked around my neck, her legs wrapped around my waist, 95 pounds that felt no more than 30. . . . It was not a greeting as much as it was a claim: she was staking out this spot on my chest as her own and I was to hold her for as long as she wanted to stay.''
 Through the turbulent years of their friendship, Grealy will continue to pitch herself into Patchett's protective arms, and Patchett will hold her for as long as she is able.
 It can be no surprise that the memoir of a friendship that ends in the premature death of a gifted writer does not make for cheerful reading. And yet there is much in ''Truth & Beauty'' that is uplifting, a testament to the perennial idealism and optimism of the young. Lucy, Patchett tells us, ''was absolutely committed to the idea that writing would be her salvation and that she was obligated to pull herself out of all her present miseries with the sheer strength of her will and talent.'' The solace of art to the lonely and dissatisfied is wonderfully rendered: ''We had each come to realize that no one was going to save our lives, and that if we wanted to save them ourselves, we had only one skill that afforded us any hope at all. Writing is a job, a talent, but it's also the place to go in your head. It is the imaginary friend you drink your tea with in the afternoon.''
 Showcased within Patchett's plain prose, Grealy's letters glow with the energy of a quirkily original voice: ''Dearest anvil, dearest deposed president of some new defunct but lovingly remembered country, dearest to me, I can find no suitable words of affection for you, words that will contain the whole of your wonderfulness to me. You will have to make due with being my favorite bagel, my favorite blue awning above some great little cafe where the coffee is strong but milky and had real texture to it.''
 The juxtaposing of these very different voices makes the memoir an inspired duet: the reader sees Grealy through Patchett's eyes, yet hears Grealy directly in her own voice. The astute, eloquent, self-scrutinizing Lucy Grealy of ''Autobiography of a Face'' doesn't quite prepare the reader for the Lucy Grealy who emerges from these pages. Here is an antic, fey, restless, demanding and exasperating child-woman. Like a Carson McCullers character, part waif, part vampire, Grealy demands constant attention:
 ''As much as Lucy liked my friends, it was important for her to know at every moment that she was my uncontested favorite. There was nothing subtle in her methodology. . . . Lucy would inevitably leave her chair at some point during the meal and come and sit in my lap. . . . Lucy would lean her head against my chest and turn her eyes up to me. 'Do you love me?' she said. 'Of course I love you.' 'Best?' 'Yes, best, but you are crushing my thigh.' Lucy sighed, contented now, and continued her conversation . . . from the comfortable vantage point of my lap, eating what she could off my plate.''
 Though ''Truth & Beauty'' is a memoir in which love is omnipresent, it may remind some readers of Ted Hughes's controversial ''Birthday Letters'' to Sylvia Plath in its way of relentlessly exposing what might be described as flaws in its subject's character. The Lucy Grealy of this book is a wholly self-absorbed young woman who borrows money she has no intention of returning and shoplifts books at poetry readings. Unpaid bills accumulate in her wake like the careless litter that infests her apartment, in which even cherished Prada dresses wind up ''all knotted up together on the floor of her closet.'' When Grealy is too depressed to open her long-accumulated mail, Patchett heroically offers to do so; the next day, hundreds of letters and bills turn up in a large Fed Ex box.
 Grealy is something of an adventuress, so needy for a man's love that she will have sex with virtual strangers; she is continually asking Patchett, ''Will I ever have sex again?'' even on days when, as Patchett points out, she has already had sex. ''But I want to know if I'm going to have it again,'' she replies.
 As Grealy's physical and mental health deteriorate, her friendship with Patchett takes on an aura of symbiotic romance. Patchett helps nurse Grealy in appallingly understaffed hospitals, and when Grealy is discharged she carries her to and from her apartment: ''Lucy was never happier than in the moments she was held and despite everything she had been through, she was incredibly happy to be out on the street in my arms. . . . There wasn't any trick to it. She was a sparrow, a match. The trick would have been to figure out a way to do it all the time so that she could have always been happy.'' Patchett appeals to Lucy to come live with her in Nashville: ''I wanted to keep her as much for myself as for her.''
 The flurry of fame in the wake of ''Autobiography of a Face'' brings some brief happiness into Grealy's life, but by the late 1990's, after continued surgeries, post-op depressions and romantic disappointments, she becomes addicted to OxyContin and finally, lethally, to heroin: ''Lucy was having the great love affair she had always dreamed of. It was dangerous and rocky, violently depleting, but in the few minutes that it was sweet it made her feel the all encompassing heat of love.'' By this time, Patchett, disapproving of her friend's drug use, is no longer in constant communication with her. When Grealy dies, alone, in a friend's apartment, Patchett is stunned and guilt-ridden. Suddenly she is left to ponder ''the second half of my life, the half that would be lived without Lucy'' -- lived without her but still haunted by her, as this riveting book makes plain.


GRAPHIC: Photo: Lucy Grealy (left) and Ann Patchett, ''The Grasshopper And The Ant.'' (Photograph by Jill Krementz/from ''Truth & Beauty: A Friendship'')

SECTION: Section 1; Column 3; National Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1542 words

HEADLINE: TIGHT OIL SUPPLY WON'T EASE SOON

BYLINE: By NEELA BANERJEE

 BODY:
Two dollars for a gallon of gas? Get used to it. High fuel prices are here to stay, at least for the near future, because no relief is in sight for tight oil supplies.
 Most oil-producing countries and the major oil companies already produce all they can. Smaller companies and wildcatters are reopening some mothballed wells, but their combined output is not nearly enough to affect the global supply. What little spare capacity there is is almost entirely in Saudi Arabia, which is willing to pump more -- but the extra oil it could produce quickly is too heavy in sulfur for the main consuming nations.
 The world economy has learned to roll with oil price spikes, so long as they are short-lived. But sustained high fuel costs will strain its ability to cope, experts say, and the current run-up is already starting to bite. 
 Wal-Mart Stores, for example, said last week that higher gasoline prices in the United States had taken an average of $7 a week out of the pockets of its customers, leaving them less to spend on other goods. Sales of some of the largest and most gas-hungry sport utility vehicles were down last month, compared with a year earlier. The nation's trade deficit widened to $46 billion in March, largely because of oil imports. And in Britain, the government is making contingency plans in case of mass protests against high fuel prices, the trade journal Platts Oilgram News reported Friday.
 The oil industry is constantly looking for new supplies, and with crude oil closing at a record high of $41.38 a barrel in New York on Friday, producers have plenty of economic incentive to step up output. But developing a new oil field takes time, and energy companies can do little to rush projects, industry experts said.
 Marathon Oil, a large independent company based in Houston, is pumping its fields flat out -- the equivalent of 365,000 barrels a day, counting crude oil and natural gas. That includes new fields in Russia that produce 15,000 barrels a day. Those fields have the potential to yield an additional 45,000 barrels, but only after five more years of investment and work, said Paul Weeditz, a company spokesman. Marathon's new projects in West Africa will take even longer. 
 ''Companies are always under pressure to grow production, so they are always trying to bring new wells on,'' Mr Weeditz said. ''Many people may think it's a matter of turning the tap on and off, and that there's excess capacity, but that's just not the case.''
 Major oil producing areas like the North Sea and Nigeria, which produce the most desirable type of oil, known as light sweet crude for its low sulfur content, are operating at capacity. So are many of the refineries that turn the oil into usable fuels. 
 United States refineries were running at 96 percent of maximum output in April, the Energy Department said. As a result, wholesale gasprices reached record highs last week, and those prices are quickly passed along to consumers at the pump. 
 ''The worrying part is that no end is in sight for the oil price rally,'' said Jan Stuart, director of energy research at Fimat USA, the brokerage unit of Societe Generale. ''Whatever is driving this upward, those factors are not changing: high demand, lower inventories, supply that is constrained, and only in part by OPEC decisions, and turmoil in the Middle East.''
 Those price records are not adjusted for inflation. Several times in the 1970's and 1980's, prices hit what would be higher levels if converted into today's money. But those spikes occurred when supplies were disrupted by the Arab oil embargo and the Iran-Iraq war. With world demand so strong today and spare capacity so slim, the oil market is highly vulnerable to any new supply disruptions.
 Many oil traders worry that terrorists may sabotage oil facilities, sending prices to new highs that could throttle the economic recovery. Since the situation in Iraq flared up last month, oil has become a prime target there. Suicide bombers tried to attack an offshore Iraqi oil terminal in late April, then blew up a major pipeline near Basra last week. Even more troubling, industry experts say, was the killing of foreign and Saudi oil workers at the Yanbu oil hub in Saudi Arabia.
 ''This is the only spare capacity you have in the world,'' said Fareed Mohamedi, chief economist for PFC Energy, a Washington consulting firm, referring to the Saudi oil industry. ''So you're going to be nervous if there is any hint of disruption.'' 
 Oil traders estimate that unrest in the Middle East has added a ''risk premium'' to the price of oil of $4 to $8 a barrel. Yet even without that turbulence, the price of oil would probably still be higher now than it has been in years, given global demand, industry experts said. 
 The unexpectedly sharp rise, to more than $40 a barrel today from less than $30 a barrel just 18 months ago, has not noticeably slowed the economic recovery in the developed world. Most industries over the last two decades have found ways to improve efficiency, producing far more goods with the same amount of energy, and the United States has had a major shift from energy-intensive industries toward the service sector.
 Even so, the world's appetite for oil is growing at its fastest rate in 16 years, according to the International Energy Agency, which tracks oil markets and stockpiles for industrialized countries. It forecast that the world would consume two million more barrels a day this year than in 2003, or 80.6 million barrels a day in all. China's great economic growth is behind much of that increase, and few analysts foresaw that either China's boom or America's recovery would be quite so robust, said Lawrence J. Goldstein, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation in New York.
 That roaring demand has eaten deeply into oil supplies. Despite lower official quotas, nearly all the members of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries are producing as much oil as possible to cash in on the high prices, and most major non-OPEC producers are doing the same. Russia, which is not an OPEC member, is something of an exception, but it is constrained by how much oil it can export through its pipelines and railways, all of them running at or near their limits. Venezuela, an OPEC member, is theoretically able to produce more oil, but its state oil company was crippled last year by a strike and an unsuccessful attempt to oust the country's president, and it has not recovered fully. 
 Analysts say that at most 2 million to 2.5 million barrels a day of spare capacity could sustain production for any length of time. Nearly all of it is in Saudi Arabia; the rest is mainly in Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates.
 For years, whatever the markets needed to stay on an even keel, the Kingdom of Saud provided. But since the late 1990's, the country has started to pursue a more independent oil policy. To increase its oil revenue and support a growing population and a generous welfare state, Saudi Arabia has chosen to hold back some production and let the price of oil rise, said Leonidas F. Drollas, chief economist with the Center for Global Energy Studies, a London consulting business. OPEC as a whole, led by Saudi Arabia, tried to cut output and make it hard for refineries to build oil stocks, driving prices higher.
 But with the price of oil at $40 a barrel and more, the Saudis are clearly unnerved. Mr. Goldstein said they are trying to sell more oil now, but have found few takers, because of the high sulfur content of their crude. Instead, refineries in China and the United States are competing for the more limited pool of low-sulfur oil. ''There is no sweet crude spare capacity anywhere in the world,'' Mr. Goldstein said. ''There is no cushion for the next surprise.''
 Major oil companies are not bringing on new wells now to take advantage of high prices, said Ann-Louise Hittle, head of macro oils at Wood Mackenzie, a consulting firm in Edinburgh. Burned in the past by price spikes that proved ephemeral, the oil industry has become extremely reluctant to invest in wells that would be unprofitable at low prices, so it has none to reopen now. 
 Increasingly, the best prospects for new oil have proved to be in places that are off limits to major foreign oil companies, said Edward D. Porter, research manager for the American Petroleum Institute, a lobbying group in Washington.
 While production is declining in areas like the North Sea and the lower 48 states, many of the most promising fields are in the Middle East. Oil companies have shelved hopes of even looking around Iraq soon because of the violence there and uncertainty about the future. Elsewhere in the region, most notably Saudi Arabia, domestic political infighting about foreign involvement in the national oil patrimony has kept out major Western companies. 
 The oil companies will keep hunting, but a significant easing of tight supplies may be several years away, industry experts say.
 ''You can't change this overnight,'' Mr. Goldstein said. ''We need investment in sweet crude production or in refineries to process high sulfur crude, but there's a gestation period. Oil producers didn't think high prices were sustainable, but now they are coming to think they are.''


GRAPHIC: Photos: Gas prices are rising from Chicago, left, to Beijing, and are expected to continue to do so because of a limited supply of oil although most oil-producing countries and the major oil companies are producing all they can. (Photo by Agence France-Presse -- Getty Images)
 (Photo by Bloomberg News)(pg. 11)
